revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/2405:204:C608:388E:50D4:AFE3:D0AA:4ADA|2405:204:C608:388E:50D4:AFE3:D0AA:4ADA]] ([[User talk:2405:204:C608:388E:50D4:AFE3:D0AA:4ADA|talk]]) to last revision by Quiddity. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{redirect|Tribals|the ancient Thracian tribe|Triballi}} {{Use British English|date=March 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} [[File:Women in tribal village, Umaria district, India.jpg|thumb|right|Women in a tribal [[Umaria district]], [[Madhya Pradesh]], India]]
'''Adivasi''' <!-- Please do not add any Indic script in this infobox, per WP:INDICSCRIPT policy. --> is the collective term for the [[indigenous peoples]] of mainland [[South Asia]].<ref name="loksabha1995">{{Citation | title=Lok Sabha Debates ser.10 Jun 41–42 1995 v.42 no.41-42 | publisher=Lok Sabha Secretariat, Parliament of India | year=1995 | accessdate=2008-11-25 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=EaRXAAAAMAAJ | quote=''... Adivasis are the aborigines of India ...''}}</ref><ref name="masani1985">{{Cite book | title=Freedom and Dissent: Essays in Honour of Minoo Masani on His Eightieth Birthday |author1=Minocheher Rustom Masani |author2=Ramaswamy Srinivasan | publisher=Democratic Research Service | year=1985 | accessdate=2008-11-25 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=v861AAAAIAAJ | quote= The Adivasis are the original inhabitants of India. That is what Adivasi means: the original inhabitant. They were the people who were there before the [[Dravidians]]. The tribals are the Gonds, the Bhils, the Murias, the Nagas and a hundred more.}}</ref><ref name="gandhi1968">{{Citation | title=The Selected Works of Mahatma Gandhi : Satyagraha in South Africa | author=Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi | publisher=Navajivan Publishing House | year=1968 | accessdate=2008-11-25 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=cApuAAAAMAAJ | quote=''... The Adivasis are the original inhabitants ...''}}</ref> Adivasi make up 8.6% of [[India]]'s population, or 104 million people, according to the [[2011 Census of India|2011 census]], and a large percentage of the [[Nepalese people|Nepal]]ese population.<ref>[http://www.censusindia.gov.in/2011census/hlo/pca/pca_pdf/PCA-CRC-0000.pdf 2011 Census Primary Census Abstract]</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Scheduled Tribes at 8.6 per cent|url=http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/scs-sts-form-25--of-population-says-census-2011-data/1109988/}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=8.6% for ST|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-cpim-demands-reservation-for-scs-sts-in-private-sector-2078034}}</ref> They comprise a substantial [[indigenous peoples|indigenous]] minority of the population of India and Nepal and a minority group of the Sri Lankan society called [[Vedda]]. The same term Adivasi is used for the ethnic minorities of [[Bangladesh]] and the native [[Tharu people]] of [[Nepal]].<ref>http://www.thedailystar.net/newDesign/news-details.php?nid=256768</ref><ref>http://genecampaign.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/Indigenous_knowledge_amongst_the_Tharus_of_the_Terai_Region_of_Uttar_Pradesh.pdf</ref> The word is also used in the same sense in [[Nepal]], as is another word, '''janajati''' ({{lang-ne|जनजाति}}; {{lang|ne-Latn|janajāti}}), although the political context differed historically under the [[Shah dynasty|Shah]] and [[Rana dynasty|Rana]] dynasties.
Adivasi societies are particularly prominent in [[Andhra Pradesh]], [[Chhattisgarh]], [[Gujarat]], [[Jharkhand]], [[Madhya Pradesh]], [[Maharashtra]], [[Odisha]], [[West Bengal]], and some north-eastern states, and the [[Andaman and Nicobar Islands]]. Many smaller tribal groups are quite sensitive to ecological degradation caused by modernisation. Both commercial forestry and intensive agriculture have proved destructive to the forests that had endured [[shifting cultivation|swidden agriculture]] for many centuries.<ref>Acharya, Deepak and Shrivastava Anshu (2008): ''Indigenous Herbal Medicines: Tribal Formulations and Traditional Herbal Practices,'' Aavishkar Publishers Distributor, Jaipur- India. {{ISBN|978-81-7910-252-7}}. pp 440</ref> Adivasis in central part of India have been victims of the [[Salwa Judum]] campaign by the Government against the [[Naxalite]] insurgency.<ref>[[Salwa Judum]]</ref>{{Better source|reason=per WP:CIRCULAR|date=September 2015}}<ref name="thehindu">{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/friday-review/theatre/bringing-rural-realities-on-stage-in-urban-india/article7592193.ece?homepage=true|publisher=thehindu.com|title=Bringing rural realities on stage in urban India – The Hindu|accessdate=2017-01-08}}</ref><ref name="achrweb">{{cite web|url=http://www.achrweb.org/Review/2006/117-06.htm|publisher=achrweb.org|title=Asian Centre for Human Rights|accessdate=2017-01-08|archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20080721200330/http://www.achrweb.org/Review/2006/117-06.htm|archive-date=21 July 2008|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> {{TOC limit}}
==Connotations of the word adivāsi== The word Adivasi means the first inhabitants or the Indigenous People, a phrase recognised by the Supreme Court of India<ref>S. Faizi & Priya K. Nair, 2016. "Adivasis: The World’s Largest Population of Indigenous People," Development, Palgrave Macmillan;Society for International Deveopment, vol. 59(3), pages 350-353, December.</ref> [[File:Tribe woman, India.jpg|thumb|170px|Woman of Banni tribe in traditional attire from [[Gujarat]]]] Although terms such as ''atavika'', ''vanavāsi'' ("forest dwellers"), or ''girijan'' ("mountain people")<ref>Elst, Koenraad: (2001)</ref> are also used for the tribes of India, ''adivāsi'' carries the specific meaning of being the original and [[indigenous peoples|autochthon]]ous inhabitants of a given region. It is a modern [[Sanskrit]] word specifically coined for that purpose in the 1930s,<ref name="barnes1995">{{Citation | title=Indigenous peoples of Asia |author1=Robert Harrison Barnes |author2=Andrew Gray |author3=Benedict Kingsbury | publisher=Association for Asian Studies | year=1995 | accessdate=2008-11-25 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=-8eBAAAAMAAJ | isbn=0-924304-14-6 | quote="The Concept of the Adivāsi: According to the political activists who coined the word in the 1930s, the "adivāsis" are the original inhabitants of the Indian subcontinent ..."}}</ref> from ''ādi'' 'beginning, origin' and ''vāsin'' 'dweller' (itself from ''vas'' 'to dwell'), thus literally meaning ‘original inhabitant’.<ref>"Adivasi, n. and adj." OED Online. Oxford University Press, June 2017. Web. 10 September 2017.</ref> Over time, unlike the terms "aborigines" or "tribes", the word "adivasi" has developed a connotation of past autonomy disrupted during the [[British Raj|British colonial period]] in India and not yet having been restored.<ref name="waite2006">{{Citation | title=Embodied Working Lives: Work and Life in Maharashtra, India | author=Louise Waite | publisher=Lexington Books | year=2006 | accessdate=2008-11-25 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=gLm6WmbFsA0C | isbn=0-7391-0876-X | quote="The scheduled tribes themselves tend to refer to their ethnic grouping as adivāsis, which means 'original inhabitant.' Hardiman continues to argue that the term adivāsi is preferable in India as it evokes a shared history of relative freedom in precolonial times ..."}}</ref>
In India, opposition to usage of the term is varied. Critics argue that the "original inhabitant" contention is based on the fact that they have no land and are therefore asking for a land reform. The adivasis argue that they have been oppressed by the "superior group" and that they require and demand a reward, more specifically land reform.<ref name="ghurye1980">{{Citation | title=The Scheduled Tribes of India | author=Govind Sadashiv Ghurye | publisher=Transaction Publishers | year=1980 | accessdate=2008-11-25 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=9qt2e8xc-M4C | isbn=0-87855-692-3 | quote="I have stated above, while ascertaining the general attitude of Mr. Jaipal Singh to tribal problems, his insistence on the term 'Adivāsi' being used for Schedule Tribes... Sir, myself I claim to an Adivāsi and an original inhabitant of the country as Mr. Jaipal Singh pal... a pseudo-ethno-historical substantiation for the term 'Adivāsi'."}}</ref> Adivasi issues are not related to land reforms but to the historical rights to the forests that were alienated during the colonial period and India finally made a law to 'undo the historical injustice' committed to the Adivasis<ref>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Scheduled_Tribes_and_Other_Traditional_Forest_Dwellers_(Recognition_of_Forest_Rights)_Act,_2006</ref>
In [[Northeast India]], the term adivāsi applies only to the [[Tea-tribes of Assam|Tea-tribes]] imported from Central India during colonial times.
==Geographical overview==
[[File:Ao tribesman at his village for festival celebration Nagaland India.jpg|thumb|160px|Naga man dressed in traditional attire from [[Nagaland]]]]
A substantial [[list of Scheduled Tribes in India]] are recognised as tribal under the [[Constitution of India]]. Tribal people constitute 8.6% of the nation's total population, over 104 million people according to the [[2011 census of India|2011 census]]. One concentration lives in a belt along the [[Himalaya]]s stretching through [[Jammu and Kashmir]], [[Himachal Pradesh]], and [[Uttarakhand]] in the west, to [[Assam]], [[Meghalaya]], [[Tripura]], [[Arunachal Pradesh]], [[Mizoram]], [[Manipur]], and [[Nagaland]] in the northeast. In the northeastern states of Arunachal Pradesh, Meghalaya, Mizoram, and Nagaland, more than 90% of the population is tribal. However, in the remaining northeast states of Assam, Manipur, [[Sikkim]], and Tripura, tribal peoples form between 20 and 30% of the population. Other tribal peoples, including the [[Santals]], live in [[Jharkhand]] and [[West Bengal]]. Central Indian states have the country's largest tribes, and, taken as a whole, roughly 75% of the total tribal population live there, although the tribal population there accounts for only around 10% of the region's total population.
Smaller numbers of tribal people are found in [[Odisha]] in eastern India; [[Karnataka]], [[Tamil Nadu]], and [[Kerala]] in southern India; in western India in [[Gujarat]] and [[Rajasthan]], and in the union territories of [[Lakshadweep]] and the [[Andaman Islands]] and [[Nicobar Islands]]. About one percent of the populations of Kerala and Tamil Nadu are tribal, whereas about six percent in [[Andhra Pradesh]] and Karnataka are members of tribes.
===Scheduled tribes=== The term 'Scheduled Tribes'(ST's) first appeared in the Constitution of India. Article 366 (25) defined scheduled tribes as "such tribes or tribal communities or parts of or groups within such tribes or tribal communities as are deemed under Article 342 to be Scheduled Tribes for the purposes of this constitution". Article 342, which is reproduced below, prescribes procedure to be followed in the matter of specification of scheduled tribes.
==Constitutional Safeguards for STs==
===Educational & Cultural Safeguards===
Art. 15(4) - Special provisions for advancement of other backward classes (which includes STs);
Art. 29 - Protection of Interests of Minorities (which includes STs);
Art. 46 - The State shall promote, with special care, the educational and economic interests of the weaker sections of the people, and in particular, of the Scheduled Castes, and the Scheduled Tribes, and shall protect them from social injustice and all forms of exploitation,
Art. 350 - Right to conserve distinct Language, Script or Culture;
Art. 350 - Instruction in Mother Tongue.
===Social Safeguard===
Art. 23 - Prohibition of traffic in human beings and beggar and other similar form of forced labour
Art. 24 - Forbidding Child Labour.
===Economic Safeguards===
Art.244 - Clause(1) Provisions of Fifth Schedule shall apply to the administration & control of the Scheduled Areas and Scheduled Tribes in any State other than the states of Assam, Meghalaya, Mizoram and Tripura which are covered under Sixth Schedule, under Clause (2) of this Article.
Art. 275 - Grants in-Aid to specified States (STs &SAs) covered under Fifth and Sixth Schedules of the Constitution.
===Political Safeguards===
Art.164 (1) - Provides for Tribal Affairs Ministers in Bihar, MP and Orissa
Art. 330 - Reservation of seats for STs in Lok Sabha
Art. 337 - Reservation of seats for STs in State Legislatures
Art. 334 - 10 years period for reservation (Amended several times to extend the period
Art. 243 - Reservation of seats in Panchayats
Art. 371 - Special provisions in respect of NE States and Sikkim
===Safeguards under Various laws===
The Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act,1989 and the Rules 1995 framed there under. Bonded Labour System (Abolition) Act 1976 (in respect of Scheduled Tribes);
The Child Labour (Prohibition and Regulation) Act1986;
States Acts & Regulations concerning alienation & restoration of land belonging to STs; Forest Conservation Act 1980; [[The_Scheduled_Tribes_and_Other_Traditional_Forest_Dwellers_(Recognition_of_Forest_Rights)_Act,_2006|Forests Right's Act 2006]];
Panchayatiraj (Extension to Scheduled Areas) Act 1996;
Minimum Wages Act 1948.
==Particularly vulnerable tribal groups== The Scheduled Tribe groups who were identified as more isolated from the wider community and who maintain a distinctive cultural identity have been categorised as 'Particularly Vulnerable Tribal Groups' (PTGs) previously known as Primitive Tribal Groups) by the Government at the Centre. So far seventy-five tribal communities have been identified as 'particularly vulnerable tribal groups' in different States of India. These hunting, food-gathering, and some agricultural communities, have been identified as less acculturated tribes among the tribal population groups and in need of special programmes for their sustainable development. The tribes are awakening and demanding their rights for special reservation quota for them.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://sci.tech-archive.net/pdf/Archive/sci.anthropology.paleo/2006-06/msg00409.pdf |title=New Book: ''Anthropology of Primitive Tribes in India'' |access-date=26 February 2009 |archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20090226073900/http://sci.tech-archive.net/pdf/Archive/sci.anthropology.paleo/2006-06/msg00409.pdf |archive-date=26 February 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==History==
===Ancient India===
Although considered uncivilised and primitive,<ref name="irudayam2004">{{Citation | title=Adivasis Speak Out: Atrocities Against Adivasis in Tamil Nadu |author1=Aloysius Irudayam |author2=Jayshree P. Mangubhai |author3=India Village Reconstruction |author4=Development Project | year=2004 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | publisher=Books for Change | url=https://books.google.com/?id=MBduAAAAMAAJ | isbn=81-87380-78-0 | quote=''... uncivilised ... These forests and land territories assume a territorial identity precisely because they are the extension of the Adivasis' collective personality ...''}}</ref> adivasis were usually not held to be intrinsically impure by surrounding (usually [[Dravidian peoples|Dravidian]] or [[Aryan]]) casted Hindu populations, unlike [[Dalit]]s, who were.{{efn|1= <ref name="barnes1995" /> ''... Although regarded by some British scholars as inferior to caste Hindus, the status of "adivasis" in practice most often paralleled that of the Hindus ... In areas where they accounted for a large proportion of the population, adivasis often wielded considerable ritual and political power, being involved in investiture of various kings and rulers throughout central India and Rajasthan ... In central India there were numerous "adivasi" kingdoms, some of which survived from medieval times to the nineteenth century ...''}}<ref name="bijoy2003">{{Citation | title=The Adivasis of India – A History of Discrimination, Conflict, and Resistance | author=C.R. Bijoy, Core Committee of the All India Coordinating Forum of Adivasis/Indigenous Peoples | journal=PUCL Bulletin |date = February 2003| accessdate=2008-11-25 | publisher=People's Union for Civil Liberties, India | url=http://www.pucl.org/Topics/Dalit-tribal/2003/adivasi.htm | quote=''... Adivasis are not, as a general rule, regarded as unclean by caste Hindus in the same way as Dalits are. But they continue to face prejudice (as lesser humans), they are socially distanced and often face violence from society ...''}}</ref> Thus, the adivasi origins of [[Valmiki]], who composed the [[Ramayana]], were acknowledged,<ref name="naik1956">{{Citation | title=The Bhils: A Study | author=Thakorlal Bharabhai Naik | year=1956 | accessdate=2008-11-25 | publisher=Bharatiya Adimjati Sevak Sangh | url=https://books.google.com/?id=NogcAAAAMAAJ | quote=''... Valmiki, from whose pen this great epic had its birth, was himself a Bhil named Valia, according to the traditional accounts of his life ...''}}</ref> as were the origins of adivasi tribes such as the [[Garasia]] and [[Bhilala]], which descended from mixed [[Rajput]] and [[Bhil people|Bhil]] marriages.<ref name="balfour1885">{{Citation | title=The Cyclopædia of India and of Eastern and Southern Asia | author=Edward Balfour | year=1885 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | publisher=Bernard Quaritch | url=https://books.google.com/?id=hVsIAAAAQAAJ | quote=''... In Mewar, the Grasia is of mixed Bhil and Rajput descent, paying tribute to the Rana of Udaipur ...''}}</ref><ref name="sinha1995">{{Citation | title=The Bhilala of Malwa | author=R.K. Sinha | year=1995 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | publisher=Anthropological survey of India | isbn=978-81-85579-08-5 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=c_ltAAAAMAAJ | quote=''... the Bhilala are commonly considered to be a mixed group who sprung from the marriage alliances of the immigrant male Rajputs and the Bhil women of the central India ...''}}</ref> Unlike the subjugation of the Dalits, the adivasis often enjoyed autonomy and, depending on region, evolved mixed hunter-gatherer and farming economies, controlling their lands as a joint [[Property|patrimony]] of the tribe.<ref name="irudayam2004" /><ref name="singh2000ds">{{Citation | title=Tribal Beliefs, Practices and Insurrections | author=R. Singh | year=2000 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | publisher=Anmol Publications Pvt. Ltd. | url=https://books.google.com/?id=MWbenCIeK6oC | isbn=81-261-0504-6 | quote=''... The Munda Parha was known as 'Manki', while his Oraon counterpart was called 'Parha Raja.' The lands these adivasis occupied were regarded to be the village's patrimony ... The Gond rajas of Chanda and Garha Mandla were not only the hereditary leaders of their Gond subjects, but also held sway over substantial communities of non-tribals who recognized them as their feudal lords ...''}}</ref><ref name="gunaji2005">{{Citation | title=Offbeat Tracks in Maharashtra: A Travel Guide | author=Milind Gunaji | year=2005 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | publisher=Popular Prakashan | url=https://books.google.com/?id=JIjmDLardesC | isbn=81-7154-669-2 | quote=''... The Navegaon is one of the forests in Maharashtra where the natives of this land still live and earn their livelihood by carrying out age old activities like hunting, gathering forest produce and ancient methods of farming. Beyond the Kamkazari lake is the Dhaavalghat, which is home to adivasis. They also have a temple here, the shrine of Lord Waghdev ...''}}</ref> In some areas, securing adivasi approval and support was considered crucial by local rulers,<ref name="barnes1995" /><ref name="sinha1987">{{Citation | title=Tribal polities and state systems in pre-colonial eastern and north eastern India | author=Surajit Sinha, Centre for Studies in Social Sciences | year=1987 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | publisher=K.P. Bagchi & Co. | url=https://books.google.com/?id=H_S1AAAAIAAJ | isbn=81-7074-014-2 | quote=... The way in which and the extent to which tribal support had been crucial in establishing a royal dynasty have been made quite clear ... tribal loyalty, help and support were essential in establishing a ruling family ...}}</ref> and larger adivasi groups were able to sustain their own kingdoms in central India.<ref name="barnes1995" /> The Meenas and Gond Rajas of Garha-Mandla and Chanda are examples of an adivasi aristocracy that ruled in this region, and were "not only the hereditary leaders of their Gond subjects, but also held sway over substantial communities of non-tribals who recognized them as their feudal lords."<ref name="singh2000ds" /><ref name="britannica1910">{{Citation | title=The Encyclopædia Britannica | author=Hugh Chisholm | year=1910 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | publisher=The Encyclopædia Britannica Co. | url=https://books.google.com/?id=g8Xtkt1Qw3oC | quote=... The 16th century saw the establishment of a powerful Gond kingdom by Sangram Sah, who succeeded in 1480 as the 47th of the petty Gond rajas of Garha-Mandla, and extended his dominions to include Saugor and Damoh on the Vindhyan plateau, Jubbulpore and Narsinghpur in the Nerbudda valley, and Seoni on the Satpura highlands ...}}</ref>
===Medieval India=== The historiography of relationships between the Advasis and the rest of the Indian society is patchy. There are references to alliances between Ahom Kings of Brahmaputra valley and the hill Nagas <ref>[http://www.pucl.org/Topics/Dalit-tribal/2003/adivasi.htm PUCL Bulletin, February 2003]</ref> This relative autonomy and collective ownership of adivasi land by adivasis was severely disrupted by the advent of the [[Mughal Empire|Mughals]] in the early 16th century. Rebellions against Mughal authority include the Bhil Rebellion of 1632 and the Bhil-Gond Insurrection of 1643<ref>P. 27 ''Madhya Pradesh: Shajapur'' By Madhya Pradesh (India)</ref> which were both pacified by Mughal soldiers. With the advent of the Kachwaha Rajputs and Mughals into their territory, the Meenas were gradually sidelined and pushed deep into the forests. As a result, historical literature has completely bypassed the Meena tribe. The combined army of Mughals and Bharmal attacked the tribal king Bada Meena and killed him damaging 52 kots and 56 gates. Bada's treasure was shared between Mughals and Bharmal.
===British period=== From the very early days of British rule, the tribesmen resented the British encroachments upon their tribal system. They were found resisting or supporting their brethren of Tamar and Jhalda in rebellion. Nor did their ''raja'' welcome the British administrative innovations.<ref>P. 219 ''Calcutta Review'' By University of Calcutta, 1964</ref> Beginning in the 18th century, the [[British Raj|British]] added to the consolidation of feudalism in India, first under the [[Jagir]]dari system and then under the [[zamindar]]i system.<ref name="chatterjee2001">{{Citation | title=A Time for Tea: Women, Labor, and Post/colonial Politics on an Indian Plantation | author=Piya Chatterjee | year=2001 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | publisher=Duke University Press | url=https://books.google.com/?id=Ldw2lX7u-HsC | isbn=0-8223-2674-4 | quote=''... Among the Munda, customary forms of land tenure known as khuntkatti stipulated that land belonged communally to the village, and customary rights of cultivation, branched from corporate ownership. Because of Mughal incursions, non-Jharkhandis began to dominate the agrarian landscape, and the finely wrought system of customary sharing of labor, produce and occupancy began to crumble. The process of dispossession and land alienation, in motion since the mid-eighteenth century, was given impetus by British policies that established both zamindari and ryotwari systems of land revenue administration. Colonial efforts toward efficient revenue collection hinged on determining legally who had proprietal rights to the land ...''}}</ref> Beginning with the [[Permanent Settlement]] imposed by the British in Bengal and Bihar, which later became the template for a deepening of feudalism throughout India, the older social and economic system in the country began to alter radically.<ref name="vanderheyden2005">{{Citation | title=Mission und macht im Wandel politischer Orientierungen: Europäische Missionsgesellschaften in politischen Spannungsfeldern in Afrika und Asien zwischen 1800 und 1945 |author1=Ulrich van der Heyden |author2=Holger Stoecker | year=2005 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | publisher=Franz Steiner Verlag | url=https://books.google.com/?id=N7JfoaVbMGgC | isbn=3-515-08423-1 | quote=... The permanent settlement Act had an adverse effect upon the fate of the Adivasis for, "the land which the aboriginals had rested from the jungle and cultivated as free men from generation was, by a stroke of pen, declared to be the property of the Raja (king) and the Jagirdars." The alien became the Zamindars (Landlords) while the sons of the soil got reduced to mere tenants. Now, it was the turn of the Jagirdars-turned-Zamindars who further started leasing out land to the newcomers, who again started encroaching Adivasi land. The [[land grabbing]] thus went on unabated. By the year 1832 about 6,411 Adivasi villages were alienated in this process ...}}</ref><ref name="ralhan2002">{{Citation | title=Encyclopaedia of Political Parties | author=O.P. Ralhan | year=2002 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | publisher=Anmol Publications Pvt. Ltd. | url=https://books.google.com/?id=_1gQS3LOafAC | isbn=81-7488-865-9 | quote=''... The Permanent Settlement was 'nothing short of the confiscation of [[raiyat]] lands in favor of the zamindars.' ... Marx says '... in Bengal as in Madras and Bombay, under the zamindari as under the ryotwari, the raiyats who form 11/12ths of the whole Indian population have been wretchedly pauperised.' To this may be added the inroads made by the Company's Government upon the village community of the tribals (the Santhals, Kols, Khasias etc.) ... There was a wholesale destruction of 'the national tradition.' Marx observes: 'England has broken down the entire framework of Indian society ...''}}</ref> Land, both forest areas belonging to adivasis and settled farmland belonging to non-adivasi peasants, was rapidly made the legal property of British-designated zamindars (landlords), who in turn moved to extract the maximum economic benefit possible from their newfound property and subjects.<ref name="kelkar1991">{{Citation | title=Gender and Tribe: Women, Land and Forests in Jharkhand |author1=Govind Kelkar |author2=Dev Nathan | year=1991 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | publisher=Kali for Women | url=https://books.google.com/?id=cTluAAAAMAAJ | isbn=1-85649-035-1 | quote=''... of the features of the adivasi land systems. These laws also showed that British colonial rule had passed on to a new stage of exploitation ... Forests were the property of the zamindar or the state ...''}}</ref> Adivasi lands sometimes experienced an influx of non-local settlers, often brought from far away (as in the case of Muslims and Sikhs brought to Kol territory)<ref name="hunter1877">{{Citation | title=A Statistical Account of Bengal |author1=William Wilson Hunter |author2=Hermann Michael Kisch |author3=Andrew Wallace Mackie |author4=Charles James O'Donnell |author5=Herbert Hope Risley | year=1877 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | publisher=Trübner | url=https://books.google.com/?id=R2MOAAAAQAAJ | quote=''... The Kol insurrection of 1831, though, no doubt, only the bursting forth of a fire that had long been smouldering, was fanned into flame by the following episode:- The brother of the Maharaja, who was holder of one of the maintenance grants which comprised Sonpur, a pargana in the southern portion of the estate, gave farms of some of the villages over the heads of the Mankis and Mundas, to certain Muhammadans, Sikhs and others, who has obtained his favour ... not only was the Manki dispossessed, but two of his sisters were seduced or ravished by these hated foreigners ... one of them ..., it was said, had abducted and dishonoured the Munda's wife ...''}}</ref> by the zamindars to better exploit local land, forest and labour.<ref name="chatterjee2001" /><ref name="vanderheyden2005" /> Deprived of the forests and resources they traditionally depended on and sometimes coerced to pay taxes, many adivasis were forced to borrow at [[Usury|usurious]] rates from moneylenders, often the zamindars themselves.<ref name="barik2006">{{Citation | title=Land and Caste Politics in Bihar | author=Radhakanta Barik | year=2006 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | publisher=Shipra Publications | url=https://books.google.com/?id=lGNuAAAAMAAJ | isbn=81-7541-305-0 | quote=''... As usually the zamindars were the moneylenders, they could pressurize the tenants to concede to high rent ...''}}</ref><ref name="sinha2005">{{Citation | title=Restless Mothers and Turbulent Daughters: Situating Tribes in Gender Studies | author=Shashank Shekhar Sinha | year=2005 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | publisher=Stree | url=https://books.google.com/?id=NzoqAAAAYAAJ | isbn=81-85604-73-8 | quote=''... In addition, many tribals were forced to pay private taxes ... ...''}}</ref> When they were unable to pay, that forced them to become [[Debt bondage|bonded labourers]] for the zamindars.<ref name="epw1974">{{Citation | title=Economic and Political Weekly | date=1974|volume= V.9|series= No.6-8 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | publisher=Sameeksha Trust | url=https://books.google.com/?id=DQUoAAAAMAAJ | quote=''... The Adivasis spend their life-times working for the landlord-moneylenders and, in some cases, even their children are forced to work for considerable parts of their lives to pay off debts ...''}}</ref> Often, far from paying off the principal of their debt, they were unable even to offset the compounding interest, and this was made the justification for their children working for the zamindar after the death of the initial borrower.<ref name="epw1974" /> In the case of the Andamanese adivasis, long isolated from the outside world in autonomous societies, mere contact with outsiders was often sufficient to set off deadly epidemics in tribal populations,<ref name="venkateswar2004">{{Citation | title=Development and Ethnocide: Colonial Practices in the Andaman Islands | author=Sita Venkateswar | publisher=IWGIA | year=2004 | isbn=87-91563-04-6 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=XFETVExNUYgC | quote=''... As I have suggested previously, it is probable that some disease was introduced among the coastal groups by Lieutenant Colebrooke and Blair's first settlement in 1789, resulting in a marked reduction of their population. The four years that the British occupied their initial site on the south-east of South Andaman were sufficient to have decimated the coastal populations of the groups referred to as Jarawa by the Aka-bea-da ...''}}</ref> and it is alleged that some sections of the British government directly attempted to destroy some tribes.<ref name="cavalli-sforza1995">{{Citation | title=The Great Human Diasporas: The History of Diversity and Evolution |author1=Luigi Luca Cavalli-Sforza |author2=Francesco Cavalli-Sforza | publisher=Basic Books | year=1995 | isbn=0-201-44231-0 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=ApuuiwUkEZ0C | quote=''... Contact with whites, and the British in particular, has virtually destroyed them. Illness, alcohol, and the will of the colonials all played their part; the British governor of the time mentions in his diary that he received instructions to destroy them with alcohol and opium. He succeeded completely with one group. The others reacted violently ...''}}</ref>
Land dispossession and subjugation by British and zamindar interests resulted in a number of adivasi revolts in the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries, such as the Santal hul (or [[Santhal rebellion]]) of 1855–56.<ref name="judge1992">{{Citation | title=Insurrection to Agitation: The Naxalite Movement in Punjab | author=Paramjit S. Judge | year=1992 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | publisher=Popular Prakashan | url=https://books.google.com/?id=HvYpVtBXw5kC | isbn=81-7154-527-0 | quote=''... The [[Santhal rebellion|Santhal insurrection]] in 1855–56 was a consequence of the establishment of the permanent Zamindari Settlement introduced by the British in 1793 as a result of which the Santhals had been dispossesed of the land that they had been cultivating for centuries. Zamindars, moneylenders, traders and government officials exploited them ruthlessly. The consequence was a violent revolt by the Santhals which could only be suppressed by the army ...''}}</ref> Although these were suppressed ruthlessly by the governing British authority (the [[East India Company]] prior to 1858, and the British government after 1858), partial restoration of privileges to adivasi elites (e.g. to ''Mankis'', the leaders of [[Munda people|Munda tribes]]) and some leniency in tax burdens resulted in relative calm, despite continuing and widespread dispossession, from the late nineteenth century onwards.<ref name="hunter1877" /><ref name="tiss1956">{{Citation | title=The Indian Journal of Social Work | date=1956|volume= v.59 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | publisher=Department of Publications, Tata Institute of Social Sciences | url=https://books.google.com/?id=q0c0AAAAIAAJ | quote=''... Revolts rose with unfailing regularity and were suppressed with treachery, brute force, tact, cooption and some reforms ...''}}</ref> The economic deprivation, in some cases, triggered internal adivasi migrations within India that would continue for another century, including as labour for the emerging tea plantations in [[Assam]].<ref name="moxham2003">{{Citation | title=Tea | author=Roy Moxham | year=2003 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | publisher=Carroll & Graf Publishers | url=https://books.google.com/?id=FAiHU5JSYwwC | isbn=0-7867-1227-9 | quote=''... many of the labourers came from Chota Nagpur District ... home to the Adivasis, the most popular workers with the planters – the '1st class jungley.' As one of the planters, David Crole, observed: 'planters, in a rough and ready way, judge the worth of a coolie by the darkness of the skin.' In the last two decades of the nineteenth century 350,000 coolies went from Chota Nagpur to Assam ...''}}</ref>
====Participation in Indian independence movement==== There were tribal reform and rebellion movements during the period of the [[British Empire]], some of which also participated in the Indian independence movement or attacked mission posts.<ref>HEUZE, Gérard: Où Va l’Inde Moderne? L’Harmattan, Paris 1993. A. Tirkey: "Evangelization among the Uraons", Indian Missiological Review, June 1997, esp. p. 30-32. Elst 2001</ref> There were several Adivasis in the [[Indian independence movement]] including Dharindhar Bhyuan, Laxman Naik, Jantya Bhil, Bangaru Devi and Rehma Vasave.
=====List of rebellions===== {{Main article|Tribal revolts in India before Indian independence}} During the period of British rule, India saw the rebellions of several [[Other Backward Class|backward castes]], mainly tribal peoples that revolted against British rule. These were:{{citation needed|date=August 2017}} *Great Kuki Invasion of 1860s *Halba rebellion (1774–79) *[[Chakma people|Chakma]] rebellion (1776–1787)<ref>Page 63 ''Tagore Without Illusions'' by Hitendra Mitra</ref> *Chuar rebellion in Bengal (1795–1800)<ref>Sameeksha Trust, P. 1229 ''Economic and Political Weekly''</ref> *Bhopalpatnam Struggle (1795) *Khurda Rebellion in [[Odisha]] (1817)<ref>[http://orissagov.nic.in/e-magazine/Orissareview/august-2007/engpdf/Page1-11.pdf P. 4 "Freedom Movement in Khurda"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071129141833/http://orissagov.nic.in/e-magazine/Orissareview/august-2007/engpdf/Page1-11.pdf |date=29 November 2007 }} Dr. Atul Chandra Pradhan</ref> *Bhil rebellion (1822–1857)<ref>P. 111 ''The Freedom Struggle in Hyderabad: A Connected Account'' By Hyderabad (India : State)</ref> *Ho-Munda Revolt(1816-1837)<ref>''Tribal struggle of Singhbhum''</ref> *Paralkot rebellion (1825) *Khond rebellion (1836) *Tarapur rebellion (1842–54) *Maria rebellion (1842–63) *First Freedom Struggle By Sidu Murmu and Kanu Murmu (1856–57) *Bhil rebellion, begun by Tantya Tope in Banswara (1858)<ref>P. 32 ''Social and Political Awakening Among the Tribals of Rajasthan'' By Gopi Nath Sharma</ref> *[[Koli people|Koli]] revolt (1859) *Gond rebellion, begun by [[Ramji Gond]] in Adilabad (1860)<ref>P. 420 ''Who's who of Freedom Struggle in Andhra Pradesh'' By Sarojini Regani</ref> *Muria rebellion (1876) *Rani rebellion (1878–82) *Bhumkal (1910) *The Kuki Uprising (1917–1919) in Manipur *[[Rampa Rebellion of 1879]], Vizagapatnam (now Visakhapatnam district) *[[Rampa Rebellion of 1922|Rampa Rebellion (1922–1924)]], Visakhapatnam district *Santhal Revolt (1885–1886) *Munda rebellion *Yadav rebellion
* Thanu Nayak arm struggle against Nizam in Telangana in 1940s
==Tribal classification criteria and demands== [[File:Great Andamanese scarification pattern 2 - 1901.jpg|right|thumb|250px|[[Scarification]], a traditional symbol of [[Great Andamanese]] tribal identity (1901 photo)]] Population complexities, and the controversies surrounding ethnicity and language in India, sometimes make the official recognition of groups as adivasis (by way of inclusion in the Scheduled Tribes list) political and contentious. However, regardless of their language family affiliations, Australoid and Negrito groups that have survived as distinct forest, mountain or island dwelling tribes in India and are often classified as adivasi.<ref name="minahan1996">{{Citation | title=Nations Without States: A Historical Dictionary of Contemporary National Movements | author=James Minahan and [[Leonard W. Doob]] | year=1996 | accessdate=2008-11-25 | isbn=0-313-28354-0 | publisher=Greenwood Press | url=https://books.google.com/?id=2yFnAAAAMAAJ | quote=''... The Adivasi tribes encompass the pre-Dravidian holdovers from ancient India ...''}}</ref> The relatively autonomous Mongoloid tribal groups of Northeastern India (including Khasis, [[Apatani people|Apatani]] and [[Naga people|Nagas]]), who are mostly Austro-Asiatic or Tibeto-Burman speakers, are also considered to be adivasis: this area comprises 7.5% of India's land area but 20% of its adivasi population.<ref name="singh2005">{{Citation | title=India |author1=Sarina Singh |author2=Joe Bindloss |author3=Paul Clammer |author4=Janine Eberle | year=2005 | accessdate=2008-11-25 | isbn=1-74059-694-3 | publisher=Lonely Planet | url=https://books.google.com/?id=Fk8FQa2ZSFQC | quote=''... Although the northeast states make up just 7.5% of the geographical area of India, the region is home to 20% of India's Adivasis (tribal people). The following are the main tribes ... Nagas ... Monpas ... Apatani & Adi ... Khasi ...''}}</ref> However, not all autonomous northeastern groups are considered adivasis; for instance, the Tibeto-Burman-speaking [[Meitei people|Meitei]] of Manipur were once tribal but, having been settled for many centuries, are caste Hindus.<ref name="singh1988js">{{Citation | title=Religion and Culture of Manipur | author=Moirangthem Kirti Singh | year=1988 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | publisher=Manas Publications | url=https://books.google.com/?id=doQeAAAAMAAJ | isbn=81-7049-021-9 | quote=''... The Meiteis began to think that root cause of their present unrest was their contact with the Mayangs, the outsider from the rest of India in matters of trade, commerce, religious belief and the designation of the Meiteis as caste Hindus in the Constitution of India. The policy of reservations for the scheduled castes and tribes in key posts began to play havoc ...''}}</ref>
It is also difficult, for a given social grouping, to definitively decide whether it is a 'caste' or a 'tribe'. A combination of internal social organisation, relationship with other groups, self-classification and perception by other groups has to be taken into account to make a categorisation, which is at best inexact and open to doubt.<ref name="raigobi1972">{{Citation | title=Man | publisher=Royal Anthropological Institute of Great Britain and Ireland | date=1972|volume= v.7 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=Ou8rAAAAMAAJ | quote=''... Nor, for that matter, does a traits approach to drawing distinctions between tribe and caste lead to any meaningful interpretation of social or civilizational processes. Social boundaries must be defined in each case (community or regional society) with reference to the modes of social classification, on the one hand, and processes of social interaction, on the other. It is in their inability to relate these two aspects of the social phenomenon through a model of social reality that most behavioural exercises come to grief ...''}}</ref> These categorisations have been diffused for thousands of years, and even ancient formulators of caste-discriminatory legal codes (which usually only applied to settled populations, and not adivasis) were unable to come up with clean distinctions.<ref name="chattopadhyaya1959">{{Citation | title=Lōkayata: A Study in Ancient Indian Materialism | author=Debiprasad Chattopadhyaya | publisher=People's Publishing House | year=1959 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=AJccAAAAMAAJ | quote=''... Even the authors of our traditional law-codes and other works did not know whether to call a particular group of backward people a caste or a tribe ...''}}</ref>
===Demands for tribal classification=== The additional difficulty in deciding whether a group meets the criteria to be adivasi or not are the aspirational movements created by the federal and state benefits, including job and educational reservations, enjoyed by groups listed as scheduled tribes (STs).<ref name="goldmann1984">{{Citation | title=From Independence to Statehood: Managing Ethnic Conflict in Five African and Asian States |author1=Robert Goldmann |author2=A. Jeyaratnam Wilson | year=1984 | accessdate =2008-11-26 | publisher=Pinter | url=https://books.google.com/?id=DVwiAAAAMAAJ | isbn=0-86187-354-8 | quote=''... Because the question of what groups are to be given preferences is constitutionally and politically open, the demand for preferences becomes a device for political mobilisation. Politicians can mobilise members of their caste, religious or linguistic community around the demand for inclusion on the list of those to be given preferences ... As preferences were extended to backward castes, and as more benefits were given to scheduled castes and scheduled tribes, the 'forward' castes have ...''}}</ref> In Manipur, Meitei commentators have pointed to the lack of scheduled tribe status as a key economic disadvantage for Meiteis competing for jobs against groups that are classified as scheduled tribes.<ref name="singh1988js" /> In Assam, [[Rajbongshi people|Rajbongshi]] representatives have demanded scheduled tribe status as well.<ref name="prakash2006">{{Citation | title=Encyclopaedia of North-east India, Vol# 2 | author=Col. Ved Prakash | year=2006 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | publisher=Atlantic Publishers & Distributors | url=https://books.google.com/?id=Z-5T8kpi5tkC | isbn=81-269-0704-5 | quote=''... An angry mob of Koch-Rajbongshis (KRs) ransacked 4-8-03 the BJP office, Guwahati, demanding ST status for the KRs ... the KRs have been demanding the ST status for long, and the Bodos are stoutly opposed to it ...''}}</ref> In Rajasthan, the [[Gujjar]] community has demanded ST status, even blockading the national capital of [[Delhi]] to press their demand.<ref name="toi2008hsfs">{{Citation | title=Gujjars enforce blockade; Delhi tense | newspaper=The Times of India | date=29 May 2008 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2008-05-29/india/27747126_1_gujjar-protesters-maharashtra-sampark-kranti-aya-nagar | quote=''... Gujjars on Thursday blocked road and rail traffic in the capital and adjoining areas as part of their 'NCR rasta roko' agitation ... The NCR agitation, called by All India Gujjar Mahasabha, is in support of the community's demand for Scheduled Tribe status in Rajasthan ...''}}</ref> However, the Government of Rajasthan declined the Gujjars' demand, stating the Gujjars are treated as upper caste and are by no means a tribe.<ref>{{Citation |title=rajasthan-government-denies-st-status-to-gujjars | newspaper=merinews | date= | accessdate= |url=http://www.merinews.com/article/rajasthan-government-denies-st-status-to-gujjars/128672.shtml}}</ref> In several cases, these claims to tribalhood are disputed by tribes who are already listed in the schedule and fear economic losses if more powerful groups are recognised as scheduled tribes; for instance, the Rajbongshi demand faces resistance from the [[Bodo people|Bodo]] tribe,<ref name="prakash2006" /> and the [[Meenas|Meena]] tribe has vigorously opposed Gujjar aspirations to be recognised as a scheduled tribe.<ref name="rediff2007jhgfd">{{Citation | title=What the Meena-Gujjar conflict is about | newspaper=Rediff | date=1 June 2007 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | url=http://www.rediff.com/news/2007/jun/01raj4.htm | quote=''... Rajasthan is sitting on a potential caste war between the Gujjars and Meenas with the former demanding their entry into the Schedule Tribes list while the Meenas are looking to keep their turf intact by resisting any tampering with the ST quota ...''}}</ref>
===Endogamy, exogamy and ethnogenesis=== Part of the challenge is that the [[endogamy|endogamous]] nature of tribes is also conformed to by the vast majority of Hindu castes. Indeed, many historians and anthropologists believe that caste endogamy reflects the once-tribal origins of the various groups who now constitute the settled Hindu castes.<ref name="rajawat2003">{{Citation | title=Scheduled Castes in India: a Comprehensive Study | author=Mamta Rajawat | publisher=Anmol Publications Pvt. Ltd. | year=2003 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=p2wbt1QDTEgC | isbn=81-261-1339-1 | quote=''... endogamy is basic to the morphology of caste but for its origin and sustenance one has to see beyond ... D.D. Kosambi says that the fusion of tribal elements into society at large lies at the foundation of the caste system; Irfan Habib concurs, suggesting that when tribal people were absorbed they brought with them their endogamous customs ...''}}</ref> Another defining feature of caste Hindu society, which is often used to contrast them with Muslim and other social groupings, is lineage/clan (or ''[[gotra]]'') and village [[exogamy]].<ref name="khan2005">{{Citation | title=Social Development in Twenty First Century | author=Mohammad Abbas Khan | publisher=Anmol Publications Pvt. Ltd. | year=2005 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=1nQZzWJDzjAC | isbn=81-261-2130-0 | quote=''... in North India, high caste Hindus regard the village as an exogamous unit. Girls born within the village are called 'village daughters' and they do not cover their faces before local men, whereas girls who come into the village by marriage do so ... With Christians and Muslims, the elementary or nuclear family is the exogamous unit. Outside of it marriages are possible ... Lineage exogamy also exists among the Muslim Gujjars of Jammu and Kashmir ...''}}</ref><ref name="weekes1984">{{Citation | title=Muslim Peoples: A World Ethnographic Survey | author=Richard V. Weekes | publisher=Greenwood Press | year=1984 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=aVdIAAAAMAAJ | isbn=0-313-24640-8 | quote=''... The preference for in-marriage produces the reticulated kinship system characteristic of Punjabi Muslim society, as opposed to Hindu lineage exogamy and preference for marriage outside one's natal village ...''}}</ref> However, these in-marriage taboos are also held ubiquitously among tribal groups, and do not serve as reliable differentiating markers between caste and tribe.<ref name="vidyarthi2004">{{Citation | title=South Asian Culture: An Anthropological Perspective | author=Lalita Prasad Vidyarthi | publisher=Oriental Publishers & Distributors | year=2004 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=HwUNAAAAIAAJ | quote=''... The tribal communities, by and large, also practise clan exogamy, which means marrying outside the totemic division of a tribe ...''}}</ref><ref name="pfeffer1982">{{Citation | title=Status and Affinity in Middle India | author=Georg Pfeffer | publisher=F. Steiner | year=1982 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=S_G1AAAAIAAJ | isbn=3-515-03913-9 | quote=''... [[Verrier Elwin|Elwin]] documents the strict observance of this rule: Out of 300 marriages recorded, not a single one broke the rule of village exogamy ...''}}</ref><ref name="sharma2004lds">{{Citation | title=Indian Society, Institutions and Change: Institutions and Change | author=Rajendra K. Sharma | publisher=Atlantic Publishers & Distributors | year=2004 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=jBOh24IJ9t8C | isbn=81-7156-665-0 | quote=''... Among many Indian tribes it is the recognized custom to marry outside the village. This restriction is prevalent in the Munda and other tribes of Chhota Nagpur of Madhya Pradesh ... the Naga tribe of Assam is divided into Khels. Khel is the name given to the residents of the particular place, and people of one Khel cannot marry each other ...''}}</ref> Again, this could be an ancient import from tribal society into settled Hindu castes.<ref name="ferreira1965">{{Citation | title=Totemism in India | author=John Vincent Ferreira | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=1965 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=u7EwAAAAMAAJ | quote=''... there is every reason to believe that the inspiration leading to the formation of exogamous gotras came from the aborigines ...''}}</ref> Tribes such as the Muslim Gujjars of Kashmir and the [[Kalash people|Kalash]] of [[Pakistan]] observe these exogamous traditions in common with caste Hindus and non-Kashmiri adivasis, though their surrounding Muslim populations do not.<ref name="khan2005" /><ref name="bock2000">{{Citation | title=Culture, Creation, and Procreation: Concepts of Kinship in South Asian Practice |author1=Monika Böck |author2=Aparna Rao | publisher=Berghahn Books | year=2000 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=6HZ-UXaU9y0C | isbn=1-57181-912-6 | quote=''... Kalasha kinship is indeed orchestrated through a rigorous system of patrilineal descent defined by lineage exogamy ... Lineage exogamy thus distinguishes Kalasha descent groups as discretely bounded corporations, in contrast to the nonexogamous 'sliding lineages' (Bacon 1956) of surrounding Muslims ...''}}</ref>
Some anthropologists, however, draw a distinction between tribes who have continued to be tribal and tribes that have been absorbed into caste society in terms of the breakdown of tribal (and therefore caste) boundaries, and the proliferation of new mixed caste groups. In other words, ethnogenesis (the construction of new ethnic identities) in tribes occurs through a fission process (where groups splinter-off as new tribes, which preserves endogamy), whereas with settled castes it usually occurs through intermixture (in violation of strict endogamy).<ref name="trautmann1997">{{Citation | title=Aryans and British India | author=Thomas R. Trautmann | publisher=University of California Press | year=1997 | accessdate=2008-11-26 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=Fu5h2T7dZFEC | isbn=0-520-20546-4 | quote=''...The radiating, segmentary character of the underlying genealogical figure requires that the specifications be unilineal ... we have in the Dharmasastra doctrine of jatis a theory of ethnogenesis through intermixture or marriage of persons of different varnas, and secondary and tertiary intermixtures of the original ones, leading to a multitude of units, rather than the radiating segmentary structure of ethnogenesis by fission or descent ...''}}</ref>
===Other criteria=== Unlike castes, which form part of a complex and interrelated local economic exchange system, tribes tend to form self-sufficient economic units. For most tribal people, land-use rights traditionally derive simply from tribal membership. Tribal society tends to the egalitarian, with its [[leadership]] based on ties of kinship and personality rather than on hereditary status. Tribes typically consist of [[segmentary lineage]]s whose extended families provide the basis for social organisation and control. Tribal religion recognises no authority outside the tribe.
Any of these criteria may not apply in specific instances. Language does not always give an accurate indicator of tribal or caste status. Especially in regions of mixed population, many tribal groups have lost their original languages and simply speak local or regional languages. In parts of Assam—an area historically divided between warring tribes and villages—increased contact among villagers began during the colonial period, and has accelerated since independence in 1947. A [[pidgin]] [[Assamese language|Assamese]] developed, whereas educated tribal members learnt [[Hindi]] and, in the late twentieth century, English.
Self-identification and group loyalty do not provide unfailing markers of tribal identity either. In the case of stratified tribes, the loyalties of clan, kin, and family may well predominate over those of tribe. In addition, tribes cannot always be viewed as people living apart; the degree of isolation of various tribes has varied tremendously. The [[Gondi people|Gond]]s, [[Santal]]s, and [[Bhil]]s traditionally have dominated the regions in which they have lived. Moreover, tribal society is not always more egalitarian than the rest of the rural populace; some of the larger tribes, such as the Gonds, are highly stratified.
The apparently wide fluctuation in estimates of South Asia's tribal population through the twentieth century gives a sense of how unclear the distinction between tribal and nontribal can be. India's 1931 census enumerated 22 million tribal people, in 1941 only 10 million were counted, but by 1961 some 30 million and in 1991 nearly 68 million tribal members were included. The differences among the figures reflect changing census criteria and the economic incentives individuals have to maintain or reject classification as a tribal member.
These gyrations of census data serve to underline the complex relationship between caste and tribe. Although, in theory, these terms represent different ways of life and ideal types, in reality they stand for a continuum of social groups. In areas of substantial contact between tribes and castes, social and cultural pressures have often tended to move tribes in the direction of becoming castes over a period of years. Tribal peoples with ambitions for social advancement in Indian society at large have tried to gain the classification of caste for their tribes. On occasion, an entire tribe or part of a tribe joined a Hindu sect and thus entered the [[Caste system in India|caste system]] ''en masse''. If a specific tribe engaged in practices that Hindus deemed polluting, the tribe's status when it was assimilated into the caste hierarchy would be affected.
==Religion== {{Main article|Tribal religions in India}} The majority of Adivasi practice Hinduism and Christianity. During the last two decades Adivasi from [[Odisha]], Madhya Pradesh, Jharkhand have converted to Protestant groups. Adivasi beliefs vary by tribe, and are usually different from the [[historical Vedic religion]], with its [[monism|monistic]] underpinnings, Indo-European deities (who are often [[cognates]] of ancient Iranian, Greek and Roman deities, e.g. [[Mitra (Vedic)|Mitra]]/[[Mithra]]/[[Mithras]]), lack of [[Idolatry|idol worship]] and lack of a concept of [[reincarnation]].<ref name="scudiere1997">{{Citation | title=Aspects of Death and Bereavement Among Indian Hindus and American Christians: A Survey and Cross-cultural Comparison | author=Todd Scudiere | publisher=University of Wisconsin – Madison | year=1997 | accessdate=2008-11-25 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=gQVlAAAAMAAJ | quote=''... the Vedic Aryan was not particularly eager to enter heaven, he was too much this-worldly oriented. A notion of reincarnation was not introduced until later. However, there was a concept of a universal force – an idea of an underlying monistic reality that was later called Brahman ...''}}</ref>
===Animism=== {{Main article|Animism}} [[Animism]] (from [[Latin]] ''animus, -i'' "[[Soul (spirit)|soul]], [[life]]") is the [[worldview]] that non-human entities (animals, plants, and inanimate objects or phenomena) possess a spiritual essence. The ''Encyclopaedia of Religion and Society'' estimates that 1–5% of India's population is animist.<ref>http://hirr.hartsem.edu/ency/Animism.htm</ref> India's government recognises that India's indigenous subscribe to pre-Hindu animist-based religions.<ref name="bbc">{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/5019582.stm#graph|publisher=news.bbc.co.uk|title=BBC NEWS | World | Europe | Indigenous people 'worst-off world over'|accessdate=2017-01-08}}</ref><ref name="google">{{cite book|title=Racism Against Indigenous Peoples|author1=Chakma, S.|author2=Jensen, M.|author3=International Work Group for Indigenous Affairs|date=2001|publisher=IWGIA|isbn=9788790730468|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f7EPoTyUvfkC&pg=PA196|page=196|accessdate=2017-01-08}}</ref>
Animism is used in the [[anthropology of religion]] as a term for the belief system of some [[indigenous people|indigenous tribal peoples]],<ref>{{cite book|title=Ritual and Belief: Readings in the Anthropology of Religion|first=David|last=Hicks|publisher=[[Rowman Altamira]]|edition=3|year=2010|page=359|quote=Tylor's notion of animism—for him the first religion—included the assumption that early ''Homo sapiens'' had invested animals and plants with souls ...}}</ref> especially prior to the development of organised religion.<ref>{{cite web|title=Animism|publisher=ELMAR Project (University of Cumbria)|date=1998–99|others=Contributed by Helen James; coordinated by Dr. Elliott Shaw with assistance from Ian Favell|url=http://www.philtar.ac.uk/encyclopedia/seasia/animism.html}}</ref> Although each culture has its own different mythologies and rituals, "animism" is said to describe the most common, foundational thread of indigenous peoples' "spiritual" or "supernatural" perspectives. The animistic perspective is so fundamental, mundane, everyday and taken-for-granted that most animistic indigenous people do not even have a word in their languages that corresponds to "animism" (or even "religion");<ref>{{cite web|title=Native American Religious and Cultural Freedom: An Introductory Essay|work=The Pluralism Project|publisher=President and Fellows of Harvard College and Diana Eck|year=2005|url=http://www.pluralism.org/reports/view/176}}</ref> the term is an [[Emic and etic|anthropological construct]] rather than one designated by the people themselves.
====Donyi-Polo==== {{Main article|Donyi-Polo}}
Donyi-Polo is the designation given to the [[indigenous religion]]s, of [[animism|animistic]] and [[shamanism|shamanic]] type, of the [[Tani languages|Tani]], from [[Arunachal Pradesh]], in northeastern India.<ref>Rikam, 2005. p. 117</ref><ref>Mibang, Chaudhuri, 2004. p. 47</ref> The name "Donyi-Polo" means "Sun-Moon".<ref>Dalmia, Sadana, 2012. pp. 44–45</ref>
====Sanamahi==== {{Main article|Sanamahism}} [[Sanamahism]] is the worship of Sanamahi, the eternal force/cells responsible for the continuity of living creations. Sanamahi referred here is not to be confused with Lainingthou Sanamahi (The Supreme House-dwelling God of the Sanamahism). The religion has a great and unique traditional history which has been preserved till date for worshipping ancestors as almighty. Thus it signifies that Sanamahism is the worship of eternal force/cells present in living creations.
Sidaba Mapu, the Creator God of Sanamahism. Sanamahism is one of the oldest religion of [[South East Asia]]. It originated in [[Manipur]] and is mainly practiced by the [[Meitei people|Meitei]], [[Kabui]], [[Zeliangrong]] and other communities who inhabit in Manipur, [[Assam]], [[Tripura]].
====Sarnaism==== {{Main article|Sarnaism}}
[[Sarnaism]] or Sarna<ref>Minahan, 2012. p. 236</ref><ref>Sachchidananda, 1980. p. 235</ref><ref>Srivastava, 2007.</ref> (local languages: ''Sarna Dhorom'', meaning "religion of the holy woods") defines the indigenous religions of the Adivasi populations of the states of Central-[[East India]], such as the [[Munda people|Munda]], the [[Ho people|Ho]], the [[Santal people|Santali]], the [[Kurukh people|Khuruk]], and the others. The Munda, Ho, Santhal and Oraon tribe followed the Sarna religion,<ref name="indiatimes">{{cite web|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-02-06/ranchi/28362611_1_tribal-population-religion-sarna|publisher=articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com|title= ST panel for independent religion status to Sarna |accessdate=2017-01-08}}</ref> where Sarna means sacred grove. Their religion is based on the oral traditions passed from generation-to-generation. It strongly believes in one God, the Great Spirit.
====Other tribal animist====
Animist hunter gatherer Nayaka people of Nigrill's hills of South India.<ref name="google2">{{cite book|title=The Encyclopedia of Religion and Nature: K – Z.|date=2005|volume=2|publisher=Thoemmes Continuum|isbn=9781843711384|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4L7UAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA82|page=82|accessdate=2017-01-08}}</ref>
Animism is the traditional religion of [[Nicobarese]] people; their religion is marked by the dominance and interplay with spirit worship, witch doctors and animal sacrifice.<ref name="google3">{{cite book|title=Andaman and Nicobar Tribes Restudied: Encounters and Concerns|author=Mann, R.S.|date=2005|publisher=Mittal Publications|isbn=9788183240109|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FPX6wiuZ3ikC&pg=PA204|page=204|accessdate=2017-01-08}}</ref>
===Hinduism===
====Adivasi roots of modern Hinduism==== Some historians and anthropologists assert that much of what constitutes [[folk Hinduism]] today is actually descended from an amalgamation of adivasi faiths, idol worship practices and deities, rather than the original Indo-Aryan faith.<ref name="sardesai1986">{{Citation | title=Progress and Conservatism in Ancient India | author=S.G. Sardesai | publisher=People's Publishing House | year=1986 | accessdate=2008-11-25 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=kscNAAAAIAAJ | quote=''... The centre of Rig Vedic religion was the Yajna, the sacrificial fire. ... There is no Atma, no Brahma, no Moksha, no idol worship in the Rig Veda ...''}}</ref><ref name="tiwari2002">{{Citation | title=Tribal Roots of Hinduism | author=Shiv Kumar Tiwari | publisher=Sarup & Sons | year=2002| accessdate=2008-12-12 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=n0gwfmPFTLgC | isbn=81-7625-299-9}}</ref><ref name="singh1985">{{Citation | title=Tribal Society in India: An Anthropo-historical Perspective | author=Kumar Suresh Singh | publisher=Manohar | year=1985 | accessdate=2008-12-12 | url=https://books.google.com/?id=WIAiAAAAMAAJ | quote=''... Shiva was a "tribal deity" to begin with and forest-dwelling communities, including those who have ceased to be tribals and those who are tribals today ...''}}</ref> This also includes the sacred status of certain animals such as monkeys, cows, fish, matsya, peacocks, cobras ([[Nāga|nagas]]) and elephants and plants such as the [[sacred fig]] (''pipal''), [[Ocimum tenuiflorum]] (''tulsi'') and [[Azadirachta indica]] (''neem''), which may once have held totemic importance for certain adivasi tribes.<ref name="tiwari2002" />
====Adivasi sants==== A sant is an Indian holy man, and a title of a devotee or ascetic, especially in north and east India. Generally a holy or saintly person is referred to as a mahatma, paramahamsa, or swami, or given the prefix Sri or Srila before their name. The term is sometimes misrepresented in English as "[[Hindu saint]]", although "sant" is unrelated to "saint".
*[[Sant (religion)|Sant]] Buddhu Bhagat, led the [[Hindu Response to Conversions#Kol Insurrection (1831-1832)|Kol Insurrection (1831–1832)]] aimed against tax imposed on Mundas by Muslim rulers. *Sant Dhira or [[Kannappa Nayanar]][http://www.shaivam.org/nakanna1.html], one of 63 Nayanar Shaivite sants, a hunter from whom Lord Shiva gladly accepted food offerings. It is said that he poured water from his mouth on the Shivlingam and offered the Lord swine flesh.[https://web.archive.org/web/20080102233739/http://www.divinelifesociety.org/graphics/ebooks/swami_sivanandaji/downnload/all_about_hinduism.html] *Sant Dhudhalinath, Gujarati, a 17th or 18th century devotee (P. 4, ''The Story of Historic People of India-The Kolis'') *Sant Ganga Narain, led the [[Hindu Response to Conversions#Bhumij Revolt (1832-1833)|Bhumij Revolt (1832–1833)]] aimed against missionaries and British colonialists. *Sant Gurudev Kalicharan Brahma or Guru Brahma, a Bodo whose founded the Brahma Dharma aimed against missionaries and colonialists. The [[Bodo Brahma Dharma|Brahma Dharma]] movement sought to unite peoples of all religions to worship God together and survives even today. *Sant Kalu Dev, Punjab, related with Fishermen community [[Nishadha]] *Sant Kubera, ethnic Gujarati, taught for over 35 years, and had 20,000 followers in his time.<ref>P. 269 ''Brāhmanism and Hindūism, Or, Religious Thought and Life in India: As Based on the Veda and Other Sacred Books of the Hindūs (Google eBook)'' by Sir Monier Monier-Williams</ref> *Sant Jatra Oraon, Oraon, led the Tana Bhagat Movement (1914–1919) aimed against the missionaries and British colonialists *Sant Tantya Mama (Bhil), a Bhil after whom a movement is named after – the "Jananayak Tantya Bhil" *Sant [[Thirumangai Alvar|Tirumangai Alvar]], [[Kallar, Trivandrum|Kallar]], composed the six Vedangas in beautiful Tamil verse [https://web.archive.org/web/20080504053609/http://www.srivaishnavan.com/tomcat/thiruppa2.htm] *Saint Kalean Guru (Kalean Murmu) is the most beloved person among Santal Tribes community who was widely popular 'Nagam Guru' Guru of Early Histories in fourteen century by the references of their forefathers.
====Sages==== *Bhakta [[Shabari]], a [[Nishadha]] woman who offered Shri Rama and Shri Laxmana her half-eaten [[Ziziphus mauritiana|ber]] fruit, which they gratefully accepted when they were searching for [[Sita|Shri Sita Devi]] in the forest.
====Maharishis==== *Maharshi Matanga, Matanga Bhil, Guru of Bhakta Shabari. In fact, Chandalas are often addressed as ‘Matanga ’in passages like Varaha Purana 1.139.91
====Avatars==== *Birsa Bhagwan or [[Birsa Munda]], considered an avatar of Khasra Kora. People approached him as Singbonga, the Sun god. His sect included Christian converts.[http://rrtd.nic.in/Birsa.html] He and his clan, the [[Mundas]], were connected with Vaishnavite traditions as they were influenced by [[Caitanya|Sri Chaitanya]].[https://archive.is/20080502212703/http://www.thetribaltribune.com/V1I2/Birsa.htm] Birsa was very close to the Panre brothers Vaishnavites. *Kirata – the form of Lord Shiva as a hunter. It is mentioned in the Mahabharata. The Karppillikkavu Sree Mahadeva Temple, Kerala adores Lord Shiva in this avatar and is known to be one of the oldest surviving temples in Bharat. *Vettakkorumakan, the son of Lord Kirata. *Kaladutaka or 'Vaikunthanatha', Kallar (robber), avatar of Lord Vishnu.[https://web.archive.org/web/20160304103825/http://www.hindubooks.org/temples/tamilnadu/srivaikuntam/page3.htm]
====Other tribals and Hinduism====
Some Hindus believe that Indian tribals are close to the romantic ideal of the ancient [[Wiktionary:silvan|silvan]] culture<ref>Thomas Parkhill: The Forest Setting in Hindu Epics.</ref> of the Vedic people. [[Madhav Sadashiv Golwalkar]] said:
{{quotation|The tribals "can be given [[Upanayana|yajñopavîta]] (...) They should be given equal rights and footings in the matter of religious rights, in temple worship, in the study of Vedas, and in general, in all our social and religious affairs. This is the only right solution for all the problems of casteism found nowadays in our Hindu society."<ref>M.S. Golwalkar: Bunch of Thoughts, p.479.</ref>}}
At the [[Lingaraj Temple]] in [[Bhubaneswar]], there are [[Brahmin]] and Badu (tribal) priests. The Badus have the most intimate contact with the deity of the temple, and only they can bathe and adorn it.<ref>JAIN, Girilal: The Hindu Phenomenon. UBSPD, Delhi 1994.</ref><ref>Eschmann, Kulke and Tripathi, eds.: Cult of Jagannath, p.97. Elst 2001</ref>
The Bhils are mentioned in the [[Mahabharata]]. The Bhil boy [[Ekalavya]]'s teacher was [[Drona]], and he had the honour to be invited to [[Yudhishthira]]'s [[Rajasuya]] [[Yajna]] at [[Indraprastha]].<ref>Mahabharata (I.31–54) (II.37.47; II.44.21) Elst 2001</ref> Indian tribals were also part of royal armies in the [[Ramayana]] and in the [[Arthashastra]].<ref>Kautilya: The Arthashastra 9:2:13-20, Penguin edition, p. 685. Elst 2001</ref>
[[Shabari]] was a Bhil woman who offered [[Rama]] and [[Lakshmana]] [[Ziziphus mauritiana|jujubes]] when they were searching for [[Sita]] in the forest. Matanga, a Bhil, became a Brahmana.{{citation needed|date=August 2011}}
ed against this custom.<ref name="telegraphindia">{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1060529/asp/jamshedpur/story_6283269.asp|publisher=telegraphindia.com|title=The Telegraph – Calcutta : Jamshedpur | Tribal groups on collision course |accessdate=2017-01-08}}</ref>{{clarify|date=August 2017}}
===Demands for a separate religious code=== Some Adivasi organisations have demanded that a distinct religious code be listed for Adivasis in the 2011 census of India. The All India Adivasi Conference was held on 1 and 2 January 2011 at Burnpur, Asansol, West Bengal. 750 delegates were present from all parts of India and cast their votes for Religion code as follows: [[Sari Dhorom]] – 632, [[Sarnaism|Sarna]] – 51, [[Kherwalism]] – 14 and Other Religions – 03. [[Census of India]].<ref>http://in.news.yahoo.com/43/20100224/812/tnl-tribals-appeal-for-separate-religion.html{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Tribal system==
Tribals are not part of the caste system,<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/4071703.stm | work=BBC News | title=Plight of India's tribal peoples | date=10 December 2004 | accessdate=2010-04-23}}</ref> and usually constitute egalitarian societies. Christian tribals do not automatically lose their traditional tribal rules.
When in 1891 a missionary asked 150 [[Munda people|Munda]] Christians to "inter-dine" with people of different rank, only 20 Christians did so, and many converts lost their new faith. Father Haghenbeek concluded on this episode that these rules are not "pagan", but a sign of "national sentiment and pride", and wrote:
{{quotation| "On the contrary, while proclaiming the equality of all men before God, we now tell them: preserve your race pure, keep our customs, refrain from eating with Lohars (blacksmiths), Turis (bamboo workers) and other people of lower rank. To become good Christians, it (inter-dining) is not required."<ref>A. Van Exem: "The Mistake, reviewed after a century", Sevartham 1991 may. Elst 2001</ref>}}
However, many scholars argue that the claim that tribals are an egalitarian society in contrast to a caste-based society is a part of a larger political agenda by some to maximise any differences from tribal and urban societies. According to scholar [[Koenraad Elst]], caste practices and social taboos among Indian tribals date back to antiquity:
{{quotation| "The Munda tribals not only practise tribal [[endogamy]] and [[Wiktionary:commensality|commensality]], but also observe a [[jâti]] division within the tribe, buttressed by notions of social pollution, a mythological explanation and harsh punishments.
A Munda Catholic theologian testifies: The tribals of [[Chhotanagpur]] are an [[endogamous]] tribe. They usually do not marry outside the tribal community, because to them the tribe is sacred. The way to salvation is the tribe. Among the Santals, it is tabooed to marry outside the tribe or inside ones clan, just as Hindus marry inside their [[caste]] and outside their [[gotra]]. More precisely: To protect their tribal solidarity, the [[Santal]]s have very stringent marriage laws. A Santal cannot marry a non-Santal or a member of his own clan. The former is considered as a threat to the tribe's integrity, while the latter is considered incestuous. Among the [[Ho language|Ho]] of Chhotanagpur, the trespasses which occasion the exclusion from the tribe without chance of appeal, are essentially those concerning endogamy and [[exogamy]]." }}
Inter-dining has also been prohibited by many Indian tribal peoples.<ref>veddha{{full|date=February 2018}}</ref>
==Adivasi (STs) Demography in India== [[File:2011 Census Scheduled Tribes distribution map India by state and union territory.svg|thumb|360px|Scheduled Tribes distribution map in India by state and union territory according to 2011 Census.<ref name=2011Census/> [[Mizoram]] and [[Lakshadweep]] had the highest % of its population as ST (~95%), while Punjab and [[Haryana]] had 0%.<ref name=2011Census>{{cite web | url=http://www.censusindia.gov.in/2011-Documents/SCST%20Presentation%2028-10-2013.ppt | title=Census of India 2011, Primary Census Abstract, Scheduled castes and scheduled tribes | publisher=Office of the Registrar General & Census Commissioner, Government of India | date=28 October 2013 | accessdate=6 October 2018 }} {{PPTlink}}</ref>]]
According to the Constitution (Scheduled Castes) Orders (Amendment) Act, 1990, Scheduled Tribe can belong to any religion. The scheduled tribe population in [[Jharkhand]] constitutes 26.2% of the state.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ranchi/Marginal-fall-in-tribal-population-in-Jharkhand/articleshow/20374392.cms|title=Marginal fall in tribal population in Jharkhand}}</ref><ref name="dailypioneer">{{cite web|url=http://www.dailypioneer.com/state-editions/ranchi/jharkhands-population-rises-sts-numbers-decline.html|publisher=dailypioneer.com|title=Jharkhand’s population rises, STs’ numbers decline|accessdate=2017-01-08}}</ref> Tribals in Jharkhand mainly follow [[Sarnaism]], an animistic religion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scroll.in/article/754985/in-jharkhands-singhbhum-religion-census-deepens-divide-among-tribals|title=In Jharkhand's Singhbhum, religion census deepens divide among tribals}}</ref> [[Chhattisgarh]] has also 32-25 per cent scheduled tribe population.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/opinion/interview/chhattisgarh-needs-a-tribal-chief-minister/article5168478.ece|title='Chhattisgarh needs a tribal Chief Minister'}}</ref><ref name="pib">{{cite web|url=http://pib.nic.in/feature/feyr2001/fjun2001/f080620012.html|publisher=pib.nic.in|title=Feature|accessdate=2017-01-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/raipur/Population-growth-rate-declines-in-Naxalite-and-tribal-areas-of-Chhattisgarh/articleshow/36010452.cms|title=Population growth rate declines in Naxalite and tribal areas of Chhattisgarh}}</ref> [[Assam]] has 40 lakh Adivasis.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Why-Assams-adivasis-are-soft-targets/articleshow/45747349.cms|title=Why Assam’s adivasis are soft targets}}</ref> Adivasis in India mainly follow [[Animism]], [[Hinduism]] and [[Christianity]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.outlookindia.com/article/adivasi-vs-vanvasi-the-hinduization-of-tribals-in-india/217974|title=Appendix F Adivasi vs Vanvasi: The Hinduization of Tribals in India}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/jharkhand/in-jharkhand-tribes-bear-the-cross-of-conversion-politics/article1-1292184.aspx|title=In Jharkhand, tribes bear the cross of conversion politics}}</ref><ref name="thehindu2">{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/opinion/op-ed/india-largely-a-country-of-immigrants/article1081343.ece|publisher=thehindu.com|title=India, largely a country of immigrants – The Hindu|accessdate=2017-01-08}}</ref>
==Education== Tribal communities in India are the least educationally developed. First generation learners have to face social, psychological and cultural barriers to get education. This has been one of the reason for poor performance of tribal students in schools.<ref name="ssa.nic.in">{{cite web|url=http://ssa.nic.in/research-studies-docs/education_tribal_children.pdf/view|publisher=web.archive.org|title=Education of Tribal Children in India — Portal|accessdate=2017-01-08|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170404082640/http://ssa.nic.in/research-studies-docs/education_tribal_children.pdf/view|archivedate=4 April 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Poor literacy rate since independence has resulted in absence of tribals in academia and higher education. The literacy rate for STs has gone up from 8.5% (male – 13.8%, female – 3.2%) in 1961 to 29.6% (male – 40.6%, female – 18.2%) in 1991 and to 40% (male – 59%, female – 37%) in 1999–2000.<ref name="ssa.nic.in"/> States with large proportion of STs like Mizoram, Nagaland and Meghalaya have high literacy rate while States with large number of tribals like Madhya Pradesh, Odisha, Rajasthan and Andhra Pradesh have low tribal literacy rate.<ref>http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0012/001202/120281e.pdf</ref> Tribal students have very high drop-out rates during school education.<ref name="newindianexpress">{{cite web|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/kerala/School-Dropout-Rate-Among-Tribals-Remains-High/2014/05/03/article2203265.ece|publisher=newindianexpress.com|title=School Dropout Rate Among Tribals Remains High- The New Indian Express|accessdate=2017-01-08}}</ref>
Extending the system of primary education into tribal areas and reserving places for needing them, they say, to work in the fields. On the other hand, in those parts of the northeast where tribes have generally been spared the wholesale onslaught of outsiders, schooling has helped tribal people to secure political and economic benefits. The education system there has provided a corps of highly trained tribal members in the professions and high-ranking administrative posts. tribal children in middle and high schools and higher education institutions are central to government policy, but efforts to improve a tribe's educational status have had mixed results. Recruitment of qualified teachers and determination of the appropriate language of instruction also remain troublesome. Commission after commission on the "language question" has called for instruction, at least at the primary level, in the students' native language. In some regions, tribal children entering school must begin by learning the official regional language, often one completely unrelated to their tribal language.
Many tribal schools are plagued by high drop-out rates. Children attend for the first three to four years of primary school and gain a smattering of knowledge, only to lapse into illiteracy later. Few who enter continue up to the tenth grade; of those who do, few manage to finish high school. Therefore, very few are eligible to attend institutions of higher education, where the high rate of attrition continues. Members of agrarian tribes like the Gonds often are reluctant to send their children to school,
An academy for teaching and preserving Adivasi languages and culture was established in 1999 by the Bhasha Research and Publication Centre. The Adivasi Academy is located at Tejgadh in Gujarat.
==Tribal languages==
*[[Mizo language]] *[[Chakma language]] *[[Kui language (India)|Kui Language]] *[[Gondi language]] *[[Ho language]]/[[Munda language|Munda]]/[[Santali language]] *[[Kurukh language]] *[[Kukni language]] *[[Gamit language]] *[[Vasavi language]]
