revision.comment: Apply [[WP:AWB/GF|Gen fix(es)]], Adding link to orphaned article, [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: n’s → n's (2)
revision.text:
{{Redirect|Catcall|the novel|Catcall (novel)|the musician|Catcall (musician)}} {{globalize|date=March 2018}} '''Street harassment''' is a form of [[sexual harassment]] that consists of unwanted comments, gestures, honking, [[wolf-whistling]]s, '''catcalling''', exposure, following, persistent sexual advances, and touching by strangers in public areas such as streets, shopping malls, and public transportation.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Cyberbullying Via Social Media|journal=[[Journal of School Violence]]|last1=Whittaker|first1=Elizabeth|author2=Robin M. Kowalski|date=2015|volume=14|issue=1|pages=11–29|doi=10.1080/15388220.2014.949377}}</ref> According to the founder of the non-profit organization ''Stop Street Harassment'', it can also consist of physically harmless behavior, such as "kissing noises" and "non-sexually explicit comments," to "more threatening behavior" like stalking, flashing, sexual assault, and rape.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Stop Street Harassment: Making Public Places Safe and Welcoming for Women|last=Kearl|first=Holly|publisher=Praeger|year=2010|isbn=978-0313384967|location=Santa Barbara, California|pages=3}}</ref>
Recipients include people of all genders, but women are much more commonly victims of harassment by men. According to ''Harvard Law Review'' (1993), street harassment is considered harassment done primarily by male strangers to females in public places.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bowman|first=Cynthia Grant|date=January 1993|title=Street Harassment and the Informal Ghettoization of Women|url=|journal=Harvard Law Review|volume=106|pages=519|via=}}</ref> In 2014, researchers from Cornell University and [[Hollaback!]] conducted the largest international cross-cultural study on street harassment. The data suggests that the majority of females have their first street harassment experience during puberty.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ihollaback.org/cornell-international-survey-on-street-harassment/|title=Street Harassment: The Largest International Cross-Cultural Study|last=|first=|date=May 2015|website=hollaback!|access-date=31 March 2018}}</ref>
In much of South Asia, public sexual harassment of women is called "[[eve teasing]]". The Spanish term ''piropos'' most widely used in Mexico holds a similar effect. Studies show that what is considered street harassment is similar around the globe.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kissling|first=Elizabeth|date=1991|title=Street harassment: The Language of Sexual Terrorism|jstor=42888749|journal=Discourse and Society|volume=2|issue=4|pages=457–458}}</ref> Many perpetrators of these actions would not characterize them as harassment, though most recipients would. Harassment can also be disproportionately directed at those with what is perceived by passers-by as a non-typical [[gender identity]] or [[sexual orientation]].<ref>{{cite web|title=What is street harassment?|url=http://www.stopstreetharassment.org/about/what-is-street-harassment/|publisher=Stop Street Harassment|accessdate=12 May 2015}}</ref>
Taking photos of strangers without permission, as [[street photography]] and [[photojournalism]] practitioners do, is not considered street harassment.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Kearl|first1=Holly|title=Stop Global Street Harassment: Growing Activism Around the World|date=August 2015|publisher=Praeger|location=Santa Barbara, California|page=2}}</ref>
== History == There is no definitive beginning of street harassment, but discussion regarding the subject began in 1944 with the rape of [[Recy Taylor]]. Rosa Parks was commissioned to investigate the crime in which Taylor, a black woman, was kidnapped and gang raped in Abbeville, Alabama. Parks responded by starting what was later dubbed the "strongest campaign for equal justice to be seen in a decade."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dailey|first=Jane|date=2011|title=At the Dark End of the Street: Black Women, Rape, and Resistance—A New History of the Civil Rights Movement from Rosa Parks to the Rise of Black Power, by Danielle L. McGuire|journal=The Journal of American History|volume=2|issue=2|pages=490–491|doi=10.1093/jahist/jar290}}</ref>
In the 1960s and 1970s, a movement called Take Back the Night gained traction. This movement, still strongly represented today, is an international protest against sexual violence against women. Take Back the Night has become a non-profit organization that aims to end all forms of sexual violence, including street harassment.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://takebackthenight.org/about-us/|title=About – Take Back the Night|website=takebackthenight.org|access-date=2018-04-13}}</ref>
In 1970, the "Wall Street Ogle-In" took place. Led by [[Karla Jay]], women marched on Wall Street with signs addressing street harassment. As a role reversal, the women catcalled the men they passed in hopes of raising awareness of the unpleasant nature of the street harassment women experience daily.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.stuffmomnevertoldyou.com/blogs/when-womens-lib-vindicated-wall-streets-original-joan-holloway.htm|title=How Wall Street's Original Joan Holloway Inspired Second-Wave Feminist Protests|date=2015-08-25|work=Stuff Mom Never Told You|access-date=2018-04-13}}</ref>
In 1994, Deirdre Davis wrote an academic article that helped clarify what street harassment is by explaining its five characteristics: 1) it takes place in a public space, 2) it most commonly occurs between men and women, 3) saying "thank you" to a harasser provokes further harassment, 4) comments often pertain to what cannot be seen on the woman's body, and 5) the harasser's comments, though disguised as compliments, are objectifying and derogatory.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Davis|first=Deirdre,|date=1994-01-01|title=The Harm That Has No Name: Street Harassment, Embodiment, and African American Women|url=http://www.escholarship.org/uc/item/83b9f21g|journal=UCLA Women's Law Journal|volume=4|issue=2}}</ref>
In 2012, the blog ''Stop Street Harassment'' became a non-profit that is "dedicated to documenting and ending gender-based street harassment worldwide" by hosting events and keeping people informed about action they can take to end street harassment.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.stopstreetharassment.org/about/|title=About |publisher=Stop Street Harassment|access-date=2018-04-13|language=English}}</ref>
==Prevalence== There is a high prevalence for street harassment to become sexual violence. Worldwide, statistics show that 80% of women endure at least frequent street harassment, 45% feel that they cannot go alone to public spaces, 50% have to cross the street to find alternate routes to their destinations, 26% claim that they are in a relationship in order to avoid harassment, 80% feel the need to be constantly alert when traversing local streets and 19% have had to switch careers to escape the area in which harassment occurred.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Meza-De-Luna|first1=M.|last2=García-Falconi|first2=S.|title=Adolescent Street Harassment in Querétaro, Mexico|journal=Affilia|date=2014|volume=30 |issue=2|pages=158–169|doi=10.1177/0886109914541117}}</ref> This problem is not only transnational, but also transcultural and affects people of all identities, races, and ages—everyday.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lennox|first1=R.|last2=Jurdi-Hage|first2=R.|title=Beyond the empirical and the discursive: The methodological implications of critical realism for street harassment research|journal=Womens Studies International Forum|volume=60|pages=23–28|doi=10.1016/j.wsif.2016.11.010|year=2017}}</ref>
The Canadian government sponsored a large survey in 1993 called the Violence Against Women Survey. In the sample of over 12,000 women, 85% said they were victims of harassment by a stranger.<ref name="JRCD" /> In a 2002 survey of [[Beijing]] residents, 58% cited public buses as a common location for sexual harassment.<ref>{{cite news|title=Harassment rampant on public transportation|url=http://app1.chinadaily.com.cn/star/2002/0411/cn8-4.html|accessdate=31 October 2014|work=Shanghai Star|date=11 April 2002|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304121955/http://app1.chinadaily.com.cn/star/2002/0411/cn8-4.html|archive-date=2016-03-04|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
A study done in Australia shows that almost 90% of women have experienced verbal or physical harassment in public one or more times in their lives. In Afghanistan, research done in the same year indicates that the prevalence of harassment was 93%. Canadian and Egyptian studies show that the rate of incidence is approximately 85% of women experiencing street harassment in the past year. In U.S.-based research, it was reported that women experienced stranger harassment on a monthly basis (41%), while a large minority reported experiencing harassment once every few days (31%). These statistics are given to show a sense of the phenomenon as widely construed, not taken as representative of the same phenomenon comparable across contexts.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Fileborn|first1=B|last2=Vera-Gray|first2=F|title='I Want to be Able to Walk the Street Without Fear': Transforming Justice for Street Harassment|journal=Feminist Legal Studies|volume=25 |issue=2|page=203|doi=10.1007/s10691-017-9350-3|year=2017}}</ref>
=== United States === A representative survey of 2,000 Americans was commissioned in 2014 by activist group Stop Street Harassment and conducted by [[GfK]]. 65% of women and 25% of men reported having been the victims of street harassment in their lives. 41% of women and 16% of men said they had been physically harassed in some way, such as by being followed, [[exhibitionism|flashed]], or groped.<ref name="SSH">{{cite web|title=Unsafe and Harassed in Public Spaces|url=http://www.stopstreetharassment.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/08/2014-National-SSH-Street-Harassment-Report.pdf|publisher=Stop Street Harassment|accessdate=31 October 2014|date=Spring 2014|format=pdf}}</ref> The perpetrators are lone men in 70% of cases for female victims and 48% of cases for male victims; 20% of men who were harassed were the victims of a lone woman.<ref name="SSH" /> For men, the most common harassment was homophobic or transphobic slurs, followed by unwanted following, then catcalling and comments on body parts. For women, the most common harassment was catcalling, followed by comments on body parts, unwanted touching or brushing up against, and then sexual slurs like "bitch" or "slut".<ref name="SSH" />
For women, most harassment is performed by a total stranger. This comes from a 1990s study from the American Midwest. It was found that numerous women have experienced street harassment on numerous occasions. Another 50% were physically harassed or followed by such strangers. Half of those surveyed revealed this harassment occurred by their 17th birthday.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://eds.a.ebscohost.com/eds/detail/detail?vid=2&sid=badf8f6d-512b-410d-a384-25507577cf5e%40sessionmgr4010&bdata=JnNpdGU9ZWRzLWxpdmUmc2NvcGU9c2l0ZQ%3d%3d#AN=linus.b3207216&db=cat00322a|title=Stop Global Street Harassment|last=Kearl|first=Holly|date=2015|website=One Search|access-date=11 April 2018}}</ref>
=== Egypt === {{Main|Mass sexual assault in Egypt}}
[[File:Tahrir Square - February 9, 2011.png|thumb|300px|[[Tahrir Square]], [[Cairo]], where [[Mass sexual assault in Egypt|hundreds of women have been pulled into crowds and sexually assaulted by men]]. The attacks sometimes last for hours.<ref name=Amnesty2015>[https://www.amnestyusa.org/sites/default/files/mde_120042015.pdf "Circles of Hell: Domestic, Public and State Violence Against Women in Egypt"], Amnesty International, January 2015.</ref>]] A 2008 survey found that 83% of Egyptian women said they had experienced sexual harassment, as did 98% of women from overseas while in Egypt.<ref>{{cite web |title=Clouds in Egypt's Sky: Sexual Harassment: From Verbal Harassment to Rape |year=2008 |last1=Hassan |first1=Rasha |last2=Shoukry |first2=Aliyaa |first3=Abul Komsan |last3=Nehad |url=http://egypt.unfpa.org/Images/Publication/2010_03/6eeeb05a-3040-42d2-9e1c-2bd2e1ac8cac.pdf |publisher=[[Egyptian Center for Women's Rights]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160320140359/http://egypt.unfpa.org/Images/Publication/2010_03/6eeeb05a-3040-42d2-9e1c-2bd2e1ac8cac.pdf |archivedate=20 March 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>{{rp|16}} A 2013 study in Egypt by [[UN Women]] found that 99.3% of female respondents said they had been sexually harassed.<ref name=unwomen2013>{{cite web|url=http://www.dgvn.de/fileadmin/user_upload/DOKUMENTE/English_Documents/Sexual-Harassment-Study-Egypt-Final-EN.pdf|title=Study on Ways and Methods to Eliminate Sexual Harassment in Egypt|publisher=UN Women| date=2013}}</ref>
Five hundred cases of mass sexual assault in Egypt were documented between June 2012 and June 2014.<ref name="Amnesty2015"/>
===LGBT community=== {{Further|LGBT rights by country or territory}}
66% of LGBT respondents in a 2012<!-- note: the data relied upon in this report is from 2012, not 2014 --> [[European Union]] survey said that they avoid [[holding hands]] in public for fear of harassment and assault. 50% said they avoid certain places or locations, and the places they listed as most unsafe to be open about their sexual orientations were "public transport" and "street, square, car parking lot, or other public space."<ref>{{cite web|title=EU LGBT survey – European Union lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender survey – Main results|url=http://fra.europa.eu/sites/default/files/fra-eu-lgbt-survey-main-results_tk3113640enc_1.pdf|publisher=[[Fundamental Rights Agency]]|accessdate=31 October 2014|pages=87–89|format=pdf|date=October 2014}}</ref>
According to the Stop Street Harassment national survey, LGBT men are 17% more likely to experience physically aggressive harassment and 20% more likely to encounter verbal harassment than heterosexual men.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hrc.org/blog/entry/lgbt=men=experience=high=rates=of=street=harassment|title=LGBT Men Experience High Rates of Street Harassment|date=June 4, 2014|publisher=Human Rights Campaign|last=Miller|first=Hayley}}{{Dead link|date=September 2016}}</ref> In a separate survey, verbal harassment was cited as the most common form of abuse.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.americanprogress.org/issues/lgbt/report/2011/07/19/9927/gay-and-transgender-discrimination-outside-the-workplace/.|title=Gay and Transgender Discrimination Outside the Workplace|last=Burns|first=Crosby|date=19 July 2011|website=American Progress|archive-url=https://www.americanprogress.org/issues/lgbt/reports/2011/07/19/9927/gay-and-transgender-discrimination-outside-the-workplace/|archive-date=19 July 2011|dead-url=No|access-date=11 April 2018}}</ref> However, there were also a significant number of people who were harassed by being denied service or being physically harassed.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.americanprogress.org/issues/lgbt/reports/2011/07/19/9927/gay-and-transgender-discrimination-outside-the-workplace/|title=Gay and Transgender Discrimination Outside the Workplace|last=Burns|first=Crosby|date=19 July 2011|website=Center for American Progress|access-date=4 April 2018}}</ref>
A sample survey of 331 LGBTQ men in 2014 indicated the phenomena occurs worldwide. 90% of them claimed to be harassed in public spaces for their perceived differences. It was mainly their lack of traditionally masculine features that singled them out for abuse. This abuse was mainly aimed at how they did not fit typical gender roles while in public.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=W_tPCgAAQBAJ&pg=PR4&lpg=PR4&dq=Kearl,+Holly.+Stop+Global+Street+Harassment:+Growing+Activism+around+the+World.+ABC-CLIO,+LLC,+2015.#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Stop Global Street Harassment|last=Kearl|first=Holly|date=2015|website=Google Books|archive-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=W_tPCgAAQBAJ&pg=PR4&lpg=PR4&dq=Kearl,+Holly.+Stop+Global+Street+Harassment:+Growing+Activism+around+the+World.+ABC-CLIO,+LLC,+2015.&source=bl&ots=qd9MCpzHfM&sig=UkMwnWhOerK7yStLjbA6OEwlZ1E&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjbgdn02bPaAhUJslQKHbuSDfgQ6AEITTAL#v=onepage&q&f=false|archive-date=2015|dead-url=No|access-date=11 April 2018|isbn=9781440840210}}</ref>
=== Health effects === A study in 2011 was aimed at recording the health effects of street harassment on women and girls. It was found that they were mentally stressed after experiencing street harassment. Poor mental health has been found to be linked to street harassment in addition to paranoia that certain spaces are not safe. The main way the women and girls put a stop to this was reducing the amount of time they spent on the street. However, this negatively impacted their ability to hold down a job or go to where they could receive healthcare.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://eds.b.ebscohost.com/eds/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?vid=2&sid=c3ba0215-5301-45f4-ab6b-d20f2035e2d3%40sessionmgr104|title=Experiences of street harassment and associations with perceptions of social cohesion among women in Mexico City|last=A Campos|first=Paola|date=1 January 2017|website=One Search|access-date=11 April 2018}}</ref>
A 2000 article, based on Canada's Violence Against Women Survey, showed that past exposure to harassment from strangers is an important factor in women's perceptions of their safety in public. Harassment from a stranger, as opposed to an acquaintance, is more likely to induce fear of sexual victimization.<ref name="JRCD">{{cite journal|last1=Macmillan|first1=Ross|last2=Nieorbisz|first2=Annette|last3=Welsh|first3=Sandy|title=Experiencing the Streets: Harassment and Perceptions of Safety among Women|journal=Journal of Research in Crime and Delinquency|date=1 August 2000|volume=37|issue=3|pages=306–322|doi=10.1177/0022427800037003003|url=http://jrc.sagepub.com/content/37/3/306.abstract|accessdate=31 October 2014}}</ref>
A study published in 2010 reported that "the experience of street harassment is directly related to a greater preoccupation with physical appearance and body shame, and is indirectly related to heightened fears of rape. ... Stranger harassment reduces feelings of safety while walking alone at night, using public transportation, walking alone in a parking garage, and while home alone at night."<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Chaudoir|first1=Stephenie R.|last2=Quinn|first2=Diane M.|title=Bystander Sexism in the Intergroup Context: The Impact of Cat-calls on Women's Reactions Towards Men|journal=Sex Roles|date=3 March 2010|volume=62|issue=9|pages=623–634|doi=10.1007/s11199-009-9735-0}}</ref>
==Motivation== In some cases, men may enjoy the thrill of doing something illegal or taboo, and some may experience sexual gratification from groping, flirting, or sexual humiliation. Negative remarks can also be the result of [[transphobia]] or [[homophobia]].{{citation_needed|reason=I realize this is considered common knowledge in feminist spaces, but someone should at least try to document it properly. Especially since the source cited in the following paragraph argues to the contrary.|date=August 2018}}
Australian reporter Eleanor Gordon-Smith recorded interactions in the 2010s in [[Kings Cross, New South Wales]], and found that men who catcalled women enjoyed getting attention, flirting, and the public performance. The men were also under the impression that the women who were the subject of their remarks and gestures enjoyed the attention and believed they were helping the women have a good time or were giving a compliment about physical appearance that would be appreciated. The vast majority of women in the area, in contrast, found such conduct degrading, wished they could avoid it, and worried that it could escalate into a physical assault. Gordon-Smith pointed out that pretending to enjoy the attention was one way to avoid provoking an escalation which could lead to a physical attack.<ref name="this_life">[https://www.thisamericanlife.org/603/once-more-with-feeling ''This American Life'' Episode 603: Once More, With Feeling Act One: Hollaback Girl]</ref>
==Public attitudes== [[YouGov]] conducted a poll of about 1,000 Americans in August 2014. In their findings, 72% said it was never appropriate to make a "catcall", 18% said it was sometimes appropriate to catcall, and 2% said it was always acceptable. The majority (55%) labelled catcalling "harassment", while 20% called it "complimentary". Americans in the 18–29 age range were the most likely to categorize catcalling as complimentary.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Moore|first1=Peter|title=Catcalling: Never OK and not a compliment|url=https://today.yougov.com/news/2014/08/15/catcalling/|publisher=YouGov|accessdate=31 October 2014}}</ref>
The vast majority of women in the Kings Cross area study found such conduct degrading, wished they could avoid it, and worried that it could escalate into a physical assault.<ref name="this_life" /> In a more representative sample, a 2014 U.S. survey found that 68% of harassed women and 49% of harassed men were "very or somewhat concerned" the situation would escalate.<ref name="SSH" /> Gordon-Smith pointed out that pretending to enjoy the attention was one way to avoid provoking an escalation which could lead to a physical attack.<ref name="this_life" /> The U.S. survey found 31% of women responded by going out with other people instead of alone, and 4% of all victims made a major life change to avoid harassment, like moving or quitting a job.<ref name="SSH" />
== Representation in media == The mainstream media, including any printed, televised, social media or other online information sources, commonly represent sexual and street harassment using overly simplified narratives and delegitimizing language. There exists a tendency in media portrayals of the issue that harassment occurs as a reflection of individual aberration, usually highlighting aspects of misconduct by one party against another.<ref name="Women 2012">{{cite journal|last1=McDonald|first1=Paula|last2=Charlesworth|first2=Sara|title=Framing Sexual Assault through Media Representations|journal=Women's Studies International Forum|date=March 2013|volume=37|issue=1|pages=95–103|doi=10.1016/j.wsif.2012.11.003}}</ref> While humanities and feminist scholarship identify any degree of sexual harassment as a manifestation of gendered oppression and discrimination in society, seldom do mainstream media sources report that harassment derives from systemic gender inequality or introduce dialogue in the context of broader issues.<ref name="Women 2012" /><ref name="Review 2014">{{cite journal|last1=Easteal et. al,|first1=Paula|title=Review: Enduring Themes and Silences in Media Portrayals of Violence against Women|journal=Women Studies International Forum|date=January 2015|volume=48|issue=1|pages=103–113|doi=10.1016/j.wsif.2014.10.015}}</ref>
Another way that mainstream media shapes the public opinion of harassment is by incorporating conservative messages to their audiences, specifically through the use of invalidating rhetoric. As with other forms of oppression against women, the language presented by media sources commonly undermines the validity of street harassment complaints.<ref name="Review 2014" /> The particular overuse of the words, "alleged," "supposed," "expected," immediately create a sense of uncertainty toward claims of harassment and assault, therefore imposing a sense of responsibility and/or guilt on to the victim.<ref name="Review 2014" />
While the internet, social media specifically, allows a new platform for activism against street harassment, it has become a source of frequent verbal harassment against users. Harassment that victims may face in real life on the streets translates to the online public forum of Twitter. In a case study following a hashtag originating in November 2011, #mencallmethings, primarily female Twitter users posted and discussed examples of the harassment they received online from men.<ref name="Conceptualizing Women 2014">{{cite journal|last1=Megarry|first1=Jessica|title=Online Incivility or Sexual Harassment? Conceptualizing Women's Experiences in the Digital Age|journal=Women's Studies International Forum|date=November 2014|volume=47|issue=1, part A|pages=46–55|doi=10.1016/j.wsif.2014.07.012}}</ref> However, over the course of this trending hashtag, tweets that were meant to educate, share stories, and create a sense of togetherness between victims often received backlash from the male Twitter user population, demonstrating that on an unmonitored media source women's voices on harassment are again silenced.<ref name="Conceptualizing Women 2014" />
While internet "trolling" (defined as aggressive online behavior) is prevalent across several internet circles, the manifestation of gendered society which normalizes street harassment, result in a specific type of Internet aggression that feminist scholars label as "gendertrolling."<ref name="search.ebscohost.com">{{cite journal|last1=Mantilla|first1=Karla|title=Gendertrolling: Misogyny Adapts to New Media|journal=Feminist Studies|date=20|issue=2013|page=53|url=electra.lmu.edu:2048/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=edsglr&AN=edsgcl.350577349&site=eds-live&scope=site}}</ref> Gendertrolling is thought to be a more threatening form of social media presence, one that aligns with the responses to the #mencallmethings posts. What allows gendertrolling to become destructive to its victims are the prescriptive signs of gender-based insults, hate speech, credible threats, unusual intensity, scope, longevity of attacks, and reaction to women speaking out, all which are similar features of street harassment.<ref name="search.ebscohost.com" />
==Activism== Public activism against street harassment has grown since the late 2000s. A group called Stop Street Harassment began as a blog in 2008 and became incorporated as a [[501(c) organization#501(c)(3)|non-profit organization]] in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=About|url=http://www.stopstreetharassment.org/about/|publisher=Stop Street Harassment|accessdate=31 October 2014}}</ref> The organization provides tips for dealing with street harassment in safe and assertive ways, as well as provide opportunities to "take community action". In 2010, Stop Street Harassment started the annual "International Anti-Street Harassment Week". During the third week in April, people from around the globe participated in "marches, rallies, workshops, and sidewalk chalkings" in an effort to gain attention for the issue.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stopstreetharassment.org/our-work/meetusonthestreet/|title=International Anti-Street Harassment Week|publisher=Stop Street Harassment}}</ref> Another group called [[Hollaback!]] was founded in 2010.
Activists have made use of [[viral video]]s to publicize the frequency of unsolicited comments that women receive in public areas.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Leeds|first1=Sarene|title=Jessica Williams Continues Her War Against Catcalls on 'The Daily Show'|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2014/10/03/jessica-williams-continues-her-war-against-catcalls-on-the-daily-show/|accessdate=31 October 2014|work=Wall Street Journal|date=3 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Hajela |first1=Deepti |title=Viral Video Documents New York Street Harassment |url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/viral-video-documents-york-street-harassment-26568112 |accessdate=31 October 2014 |agency=Associated Press |publisher=ABC News |date=30 October 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141031005238/http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/viral-video-documents-york-street-harassment-26568112 |archivedate=31 October 2014 |df= }}</ref>
One American [[street art]]ist used [[Kickstarter]] to raise money for a campaign called "Stop Telling Women to Smile." The artist posts portraits of herself and other young women accompanied with messages against street harassment.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lee|first1=Felicia R.|title=An Artist Demands Civility on the Street With Grit and Buckets of Paste|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/10/arts/design/tatyana-fazlalizadeh-takes-her-public-art-project-to-georgia.html|accessdate=4 November 2014|work=New York Times|date=9 April 2014}}</ref>
A [[Minneapolis]] woman created a set of printable "Cards Against Harassment" (in homage to the game ''[[Cards Against Humanity]]'') that she distributes to street harassers. The cards are meant to explain to street harassers why their comments are unwanted.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Silva|first1=Estey|title=Cards Against Harassment address street harassers directly|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/The-Culture/Family/Modern-Parenthood/2014/0724/Cards-Against-Harassment-address-street-harassers-directly|accessdate=4 November 2014|work=Christian Science Monitor|date=24 July 2014}}</ref>
The Safe Cities Global Initiative created by UN-Habitat in 1996 is an approach to address harassment in public places through partnerships with cities’ communities, local organizations, and municipal governments. Actions taken to address this include improved street designs and lighting in urban areas.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.stopstreetharassment.org/2013/05/2013-un-csw/|title=2013 UN Comission on the Status of Women|last=Kearl|first=Holly|date=28 May 2013|website=Stop Street Harassment|access-date=31 March 2018}}</ref> The United Nations Commission of the Status of Women (CSW), a subcategory under UN Women, is committed to empowering women and advocating for gender equality.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unwomen.org/en/csw|title=Commission on the Status of Women|last=|first=|date=|website=UN Women|access-date=28 March 2018}}</ref> For the first time, it included multiple clauses into their "[http://www.un.org/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=E/2013/27 Agreed Conclusions]" that focused on sexual harassment in public places in March 2013.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.stopstreetharassment.org/2013/05/2013-un-csw/|title=2013 UN Comission on the Status of Women|last=Kearl|first=Holly|date=28 May 2013|website=Stop Street Harassment|access-date=1 April 2018}}</ref>
A 2016 study in ''The'' ''British Journal of Criminology'' examines the extent to which online sites serve as a form of informal justice for street harassment victims. The results show that individuals experience “validation” or “affirmation” after self-disclosing their experiences online and may receive acknowledgement or support by doing so. Notably, some individuals feel re-victimized or experience re-traumatization. It was found that online justice is limited, but in particular for street harassment, it is possible that victims achieve some form of justice.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fileborn|first=Bianca|date=November 2017|title=Justice 2.0: Street harassment victims' use of social media and online activism as sites of informal justice|url=https://academic.oup.com/bjc/article/57/6/1482/2698882|journal=The British Journal of Criminology|volume=57|pages=1482–1501|via=}}</ref>
==Legal status== In some jurisdiction there are laws that make some forms of street harassment illegal. Peru has had anti-street harassment laws since March 2015.<ref name="economist.com">{{cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/news/americas/21651849-crackdown-public-displays-machismo-criminalising-catcallers|title=Criminalising the catcallers|work=The Economist|date=May 23, 2015|accessdate=January 1, 2016}}</ref>
[[Quezon City]] in the [[Philippines]], which has a high rate of street harassment,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Rodriguez|first1=Fritzie|title=The streets that haunt Filipino women|url=http://www.rappler.com/move-ph/124993-sexual-harassment-women-streets|accessdate=June 2, 2016|agency=[[Rappler]]|date=March 8, 2016}}</ref> implemented an ordinance against street harassment, such as cat-calling and wolf-whistling, on May 16, 2016. Penalties for acts of street harassment include [[Fine (penalty)|fines]] of [[Philippine peso|Php]] 1,000 to Php 5,000 and a 1-month jail term.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sauler|first1=Erika|title=In QC, wolf whistles can land you to jail|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/788539/in-qc-wolf-whistles-can-land-you-in-jail|accessdate=June 2, 2016|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|date=June 1, 2016}}</ref>
Across the United States, laws regarding street harassment are under the jurisdiction of individual states. In Illinois there are laws that relate to street harassment.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.stopstreetharassment.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/SSH-KYR-Illinois.pdf|title=Illinois|last=|first=|date=|website=Stop Street Harassment|access-date=March 10, 2018}}</ref>
Despite being a potential precursor to physical assault and even murder, offensive speech and [[hate speech]] are protected under the [[First Amendment]]. Although a perpetrator is legally allowed to shout obscenities, other acts such as public indecency and sexual assault are blatant violations of the law. Offensive speech and hate speech as forms of street harassment are frequently used as evidence against repeat offenders.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Logan|first=Laura S.|date=2015-03-01|title=Street Harassment: Current and Promising Avenues for Researchers and Activists|journal=Sociology Compass|volume=9|issue=3|pages=196–211|doi=10.1111/soc4.12248|issn=1751-9020}}</ref>
The public's rejection of criminalizing offensive speech and hate speech in view of the First Amendment poses a challenge for the legal system. Contrary to popular belief, it is not just those who are unaffected by street harassment that hold this ideal; victims and survivors of offensive speech and hate speech are reluctant to advocate against this First Amendment right. Adversely, the public is hesitant to rely on the law in their daily lives as they prefer autonomy, regardless of how grave the situation may be.<ref name="Nielsen 2000 1055–1090">{{Cite journal|last=Nielsen|first=Laura Beth|date=2000|title=Situating Legal Consciousness: Experiences and Attitudes of Ordinary Citizens about Law and Street Harassment|jstor=3115131|journal=Law & Society Review|volume=34|issue=4|pages=1055–1090|doi=10.2307/3115131}}</ref>
Not only is there a sense of powerlessness when being victimized during street harassment, but also during the legal process. More often than not, plaintiffs are unprepared for litigation and the courtroom as they are inexperienced, to no fault of their own. Quite frequently, plaintiffs are victims of legal aggression via their street harassment perpetrator. Perpetrators will file a frivolous lawsuit in response to their victim's charges. In addition to this, it is difficult to acquire government aid, as seen in the 1994 case when the EEOC received 11,000 harassment complaints and prosecuted fifty.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Stambaugh|first=Phoebe Morgan|date=1997|title=The Power of Law and the Sexual Harassment Complaints of Women|jstor=4316504|journal=NWSA Journal|volume=9|issue=2|pages=23–42}}</ref>
In a series of interviews conducted by Laura Beth Nielson in 2000, regarding the attitudes of the public in relation to the law and street harassment, four paradigms were offered. The freedom of speech paradigm is based on the ideal of allegiance to the First Amendment's supposed ideology. The autonomy paradigm is based on the desire for self-governance. The impracticality paradigm is based on the impossibility of regulation in regards to offensive speech and hate speech. Lastly, the distrust of authority paradigm is based on the lack of faith in legal officials to enforce laws. These four paradigms exemplify the reasoning behind the lack of criminalization for street harassment.<ref name="Nielsen 2000 1055–1090"/>
==See also== * ''[[War Zone (film)|War Zone]]'' – a documentary on the topic * ''[[10 Hours of Walking in NYC as a Woman]]'', an experiment where a woman walks through the streets of [[New York City]] with a hidden camera recording her from the front, and experiences 108 instances of what the video creators call street harassment over the course of 10 hours.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{cite web|title=Statistics - Academic and Community Studies|url=http://www.stopstreetharassment.org/resources/statistics/statistics-academic-studies/|publisher=Stop Street Harassment}} (worldwide)
[[Category:Sexual harassment]] [[Category:Feminism]]

page.title: Teenage pregnancy in the United States

revision.comment: Per the source, this is data for the year 2010.
revision.text:
{{Dablink|The article is about teen pregnancy in the United States. For a broader view see [[Teen pregnancy]] and [[Adolescent sexuality in the United States]].}} {{Use mdy dates|date=March 2016}} {{Multiple issues| {{lead too short|date=February 2016}} {{update|date=July 2015}} }} '''Teenage pregnancy in the United States''' relates to girls under the age of 20 who become [[pregnant]]. 89% of these births take place out-of-wedlock.{{Cite web|url=http://www.brookings.edu/research/papers/1996/08/childrenfamilies-akerlof|title=An Analysis of Out-Of-Wedlock Births in the United States|date=1996-08-01|website=The Brookings Institution|language=en|access-date=2016-03-08}} In the 2010s, teen pregnancy has declined almost continuously. [[File:Anti-teenage pregnancy III.jpg|thumb|An anti-teenage pregnancy poster]] ==Pregnancies== According to the Centers for Disease Control, more than 4 out of 5, or 80%, of teenage pregnancies are unintended.{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/reproductivehealth/unintendedpregnancy/|title=Unintended Pregnancy Prevention {{!}} Unintended Pregnancy {{!}} Reproductive Health {{!}} CDC|website=www.cdc.gov|access-date=2016-04-20}} In 2010, of the majority of pregnancies to adolescent females in the United States, an estimated 60% ended in live birth, 15% ended in miscarriage, and 30% in abortion.{{Cite web|url=https://www.hhs.gov/ash/oah/adolescent-health-topics/reproductive-health/teen-pregnancy/trends.html|title=The Office of Adolescent Health, U.S. Department of Health and Human Services|website=Office of Adolescent Health|access-date=2016-04-20}} In 2012, there were 104,700 maternal hospital stays for pregnant teens; the number of hospital stays for teen pregnancies decreased by 47 percent from 2000-2012.{{cite web |vauthors=Witt WP, Wiess AJ, Elixhauser A | title = Overview of Hospital Stays for Children in the United States, 2012 | work = HCUP Statistical Brief #186 | publisher = Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality | location = Rockville, MD | date = December 2014 | url =https://www.hcup-us.ahrq.gov/reports/statbriefs/sb187-Hospital-Stays-Children-2012.jsp}} In 2014, 249,078 babies were born to women aged 15 – 19 years old. This is a birth rate of 24.2 per 1000 women.{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/teenpregnancy/about/index.htm|title=About Teen Pregnancy {{!}} Teen Pregnancy {{!}} Reproductive Health {{!}} CDC|website=www.cdc.gov|access-date=2016-04-20}} However, most adolescents who give birth are over the age of 18. In 2014, 73% of teen births occurred in 18-19 year olds. Pregnancies are much less common among girls younger than 15. In 2008, 6.6 pregnancies occurred per 1,000 teens aged 13–14. In other words, fewer than 1% of teens younger than 15 became pregnant in 2008. Pregnant teenagers tend to gain less weight than older mothers, due to the fact that they are still growing and fighting for nutrients with the baby during the pregnancy.{{Cite journal|last=Chen|first=X.-K.|last2=Wen|first2=S. W.|last3=Fleming|first3=N.|last4=Demissie|first4=K.|last5=Rhoads|first5=G. G.|last6=Walker|first6=M.|date=2007-04-01|title=Teenage pregnancy and adverse birth outcomes: a large population based retrospective cohort study|url=https://academic.oup.com/ije/article/36/2/368/718213/Teenage-pregnancy-and-adverse-birth-outcomes-a|journal=International Journal of Epidemiology|language=en|volume=36|issue=2|pages=368–373|doi=10.1093/ije/dyl284|issn=0300-5771}} Teen pregnancy is defined as pregnancies in women under the age of 20, regardless of marital status. Teen pregnancy rates have dropped 9% since 2013. Between 1991 and 2014, teenage birth rates dropped 61% nationwide.{{Cite web|url=https://thenationalcampaign.org/data/compare/1678|title=Data|website=thenationalcampaign.org|access-date=2016-04-20}} Teenage [[birth rate]]s, as opposed to pregnancies, peaked in 1991, when there were 61.8 births per 1,000 teens, and the rate dropped in 17 of the 19 years that followed. 3 in 10 American girls will get pregnant before age 20. That are almost 750,000 pregnancies a year.{{Cite web|url=https://www.dosomething.org/us/facts/11-facts-about-teen-pregnancy|title=11 Facts About Teen Pregnancy {{!}} DoSomething.org {{!}} Volunteer for Social Change|website=www.dosomething.org|access-date=2016-04-20}} Nearly 89% of teenage births occur outside of marriage. Of all women, 16% will be teen mothers. The largest increases in unintended pregnancies were found among women who were cohabiting, had lower education, and low income. ==By ethnicity== Black, Latina, and American Indian youth experience the highest rates of teenage pregnancy and childbirth. Studies show that Asians (23 per 1,000) and whites (43 per 1,000) have lower rates of pregnancy before the age of 20. The pregnancy rate among black teens decreased 48% between 1990 and 2008, more than the overall U.S. teen pregnancy rate declined during the same period (42%). The teen birth rate decline broken down by race in 2014 from 2013: * 7% for Non-Hispanic Whites * 11% for Non-Hispanic Blacks * 9% Hispanic * 11% Asian/Pacific Islander * 12% American Indian/Alaska Natives ==By region== [[File:United States Map of Teen Births (Age 15-19) per 1,000 People by State (2014).svg|thumb|350px|Teen births (age 15–19) per 1,000 people by state (2014)
{{legend|#f8ecec|14.7 - 18.5}} {{legend|#edd1d1|18.5 - 24.2}} {{legend|#e4b4b4|24.2 - 29}} {{legend|#dc9595|29 - 33.7}} {{legend|#d57676|33.7 - 38.5}} {{legend|#cf5555|38.5 - 43.6}} {{legend|#CA3434|43.6 - 48.6}} {{legend|#7b0000|48.6 - 51.5}}]] Teen birth rates in the United States are higher than that of many other developed countries. In 2013, the lowest birth rates were reported in the Northeast, while the highest rates were located in the south east. For example, a 2001 study by UNICEF found that the US teenage birth rate was the highest among 28 OECD nations in the review; in a 1999 comparison by the [[Guttmacher Institute]], U.S. teen pregnancy and teen birth rates were the second-highest among the 46 developed countries studied. In 2002, the U.S. was rated 84th out of 170 [[World Health Organization]] member countries based on teenage fertility rate. Sexually active teens in the US are less likely to use any contraceptive method, including [[condoms]], and are especially less likely to use highly effective [[Hormonal contraception|hormonal methods]], primarily the pill, than their peers in other countries. Among adolescents who had sex in the past month: almost 25% of males and 40% of females did not use a condom. The research also found that US teens who become pregnant are less likely to choose abortion. This could be due to the fact that the resources for abortions are not readily available. 75% of women in rural areas have to drive at least 50 miles for abortion services.{{Cite web|url=http://www.itsyoursexlife.com/pregnancy/article/teen-moms-abortion-stats-you-should-know|title=Teen Moms + Abortion: Stats You Should Know |website=www.itsyoursexlife.com|access-date=2016-04-20}} 87% of United States counties do not have an abortion provider. ===Birth and abortion rates of women and girls ages 15–19, 2010 {{Citation | last = Kost | first = Kathryn | author-link = | last2 = Henshaw | first2 = Stanley | author2-link = | title = U.S. Teenage Pregnancies, Births and Abortions, 2010:National and State Trends by Age, Race and Ethnicity | publisher = | date = | year = 2014 | url = http://www.guttmacher.org/pubs/USTPtrends10.pdf | accessdate = June 8, 2015}} === {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" !US State !Pregnancy rate !Birthrate !Abortion rate !% aborted |- | [[Alabama]] || 62 || 32 || 9 || 17 |- | [[Alaska]] || 64 || 27.8 || 17 || 30 |- | [[Arizona]] || 60 || 29.9 || 9 || 18 |- | [[Arkansas]] || 73 || 39.5 || 9 || 14 |- | [[California]] || 59 || 21.1 || 19 || 38 |- | [[Colorado]] || 50 || 20.3 || 10 || 20 |- | [[Connecticut]] || 44 || 11.5 || 20 || 52 |- | [[Delaware]] || 15 || 20.7 || 28 || 47 |- | [[District of Columbia|Washington, D.C.]] || 90 || 28.4 || 32 || 41 |- | [[Florida]] || 60 || 22.5 || 19 || 38 |- | [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] || 64 || 28.4 || 13 || 24 |- | [[Hawaii]] || 65 || 23.1 || 23 || 42 |- | [[Idaho]] || 47 || 23.2 || 7 || 17 |- | [[Illinois]] || 57 || 22.8 || 15 || 32 |- | [[Indiana]] || 53 || 28 || 7 || 16 |- | [[Iowa]] || 44 || 19.8 || 9 || 23 |- | [[Kansas]] || 53 || 27.6 || 5 || 12 |- | [[Kentucky]] || 62 || 35.3 || 6 || 12 |- | [[Louisiana]] || 69 || 35.8 || 10 || 18 |- | [[Maine]] || 37 || 16.5 || 10 || 31 |- | [[Maryland]] || 57 || 17.8 || 22 || 45 |- | [[Massachusetts]] || 37 || 10.6 || 14 || 46 |- | [[Michigan]] || 52 || 21.1 || 14 || 32 |- | [[Minnesota]] || 36 || 15.5 || 8 || 25 |- | [[Mississippi]] || 76 || 38 || 9 || 14 |- | [[Missouri]] || 54 || 27.2 || 9 || 19 |- | [[Montana]] || 53 || 26.4 || 10 || 21 |- | [[Nebraska]] || 43 || 22.2 || 5 || 14 |- | [[Nevada]] || 68 || 28.5 || 20 || 34 |- | [[New Hampshire]] || 28 || 11 || 8 || 35 |- | [[New Jersey]] || 51 || 13.1 || 24 || 55 |- | [[New Mexico]] || 80 || 37.8 || 15 || 22 |- | [[New York (state)|New York]] || 63 || 16.1 || 32 || 58 |- | [[North Carolina]] || 59 || 25.9 || 12 || 24 |- | [[North Dakota]] || 42 || 23.9 || 6 || 18 |- | [[Ohio]] || 54 || 25.1 || 12 || 25 |- | [[Oklahoma]] || 69 || 38.5 || 8 || 13 |- | [[Oregon]] || 47 || 19.3 || 12 || 29 |- | [[Pennsylvania]] || 49 || 13.8 || 15 || 35 |- | [[Rhode Island]] || 44 || 15.8 || 16 || 41 |- | [[South Carolina]] || 65 || 28.5 || 13 || 23 |- | [[South Dakota]] || 47 || 26.2 || 4 || 11 |- | [[Tennessee]] || 62 || 33 || 9 || 18 |- | [[Texas]] || 73 || 37.8 || 9 || 15 |- | [[Utah]] || 38 || 19.4 || 4 || 13 |- | [[Vermont]] || 32 || 14.2 || 9 || 34 |- | [[Virginia]] || 48 || 18.4 || 14 || 33 |- | [[Washington (state)|Washington]] || 49 || 19.1 || 16 || 37 |- | [[West Virginia]] || 64 || 36.6 || 9 || 17 |- | [[Wisconsin]] || 39 || 18 || 7 || 21 |- | [[Wyoming]] || 56 || 30.1 || 8 || 17 |} ==Parenting as a teenager== There were 334,000 births among girls aged 19 or younger in 2011, representing 8% of all U.S. births. Births to teen mothers peaked in 1991 at 62 births per 1,000 girls. This rate was halved by 2011 when there were 31 births per 1,000 girls. About 25% of teenage mothers have a second child within 24 months of the first birth.{{Cite web|url=http://www.scaany.org/documents/teen_pregnancy_dec08.pdf|title=Teenage Births: Outcomes for Young Parents and Their Children|date=December 2008|website=|publisher=|access-date=2016-04-19}} Teenagers are becoming better contracepters because they realize that their sexual partners may not be a reliable coparent. Marriage rates over the 1990s through the 2010s with teenagers has drastically declined because of this realization. Since contraception has become more obtainable for teenagers, they are preventing unwanted pregnancies.{{Cite journal|last=Furstenberg|first=Frank|date=2016-11-01|title=Reconsidering Teenage Pregnancy and Parenthood|url=http://www.mdpi.com/2075-4698/6/4/33|journal=Societies|language=en|volume=6|issue=4|pages=33|doi=10.3390/soc6040033}} For every 1,000 black boys in the United States, 29 of them are fathers, compared to 14 per 1,000 white boys. The rate of teen fatherhood declined 36% between 1991 and 2010, from 25 to 16 per 1,000 males aged 15–19. This decline was more substantial among blacks than among whites (50% vs. 26%) and about half of the rate among teen girls. Nearly 80% of teenage fathers do not marry the teenage mother of their child.{{Cite web|url=http://www.teenshelter.org/Jims_Statistics_on_Teenage_Pregnancy_11-11-06.pdf|title=Statistics on Teenage Pregnancy|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=2016-04-19}} Teenage fathers have 10-15% lower annual earnings than teenagers who do not father children. Most female teens report that they would be very upset (58%) or a little upset (29%) if they got pregnant, while the remaining 13% report that they would be a little or very pleased. Most male teens report that they would be very upset (47%) or a little upset (34%) if they got someone pregnant, while the remaining 18% report that they would be a little or very pleased. Parenting as a teenager has detrimental effects on the children. Children born to teenage mothers are more likely to: be born prematurely, 50% more likely to repeat a grade, live in poverty, and suffer higher rates of abuse. The sons of teen mothers are 13% more likely to end up incarcerated, and the daughters of teenage mothers are 22% more likely to become teenage mothers. More than 25% of teen mothers live in poverty during their 20s. Teenage pregnancy imposes lasting hardships on two generations: mother and child. Evidence from U.S. studies show that women who bear their first child at an early age bear more children rapidly and have more unwanted and out-of-wedlock births. Children of teenage parents are more likely to have lower academic achievements and tend to repeat the cycle of early marriage and early childbearing of their parents.Myers, Wendy S. "Babies Having Babies. (Cover Story)." ''Women In Business'' 42.4 (1990): 18-20. ''Academic Search Complete''. Web. 25 Oct. 2016. Since the Great Recession, young people take three times longer to gain financial independence than it took for young people three decades ago. It is much harder for teenage parents to be able to support a family compared to the past due to the competitive work environment. ==Supporting teenage parents== More than 50% of teenage mothers do not graduate from high school. Some high schools in the United States offer a program for pregnant and parenting teens to continue their education. These are sometimes referred to as "Teen Parent Programs".{{cite news|url=http://www.valleymorningstar.com/news/local_news/article_551867df-5905-51de-8c65-aa26244343a8.html|title=Teen Parenting Program aims to keep young mothers in school|work=Valley Morning Star|author=Martinez, D. |date=February 7, 2009|accessdate=29 April 2016|quote=Saenz said the program, which follows a TEA curriculum, reaches out to girls and boys from middle school to high school who are facing a pregnancy to educate them about the parenting process, resources, federal programs and continuing their education.}} There are several benefits to these school based programs, the number one benefit being teens are able to continue their high school education. Studies have shown that when teen parents stay in school after being pregnant, they have a better chance of graduating high school.{{cite journal | author = Sadler L. S., Swartz M. K., Ryan-Krause P., Seitz V., Meadows-Oliver M., Grey M., Clemmens D. A. | year = 2007 | title = Promising Outcomes in Teen Mothers Enrolled in a School-Based Parent Support Program and Child Care Center | url = | journal = Journal of School Health | volume = 77 | issue = 3| pages = 121–130 | doi = 10.1111/j.1746-1561.2007.00181.x }} Less than 2% of teen moms earn a college degree by age 30. Many of these programs offer on-campus childcare. Some even require the pregnant and parenting teens to attend parenting classes or practicum classes. The parenting classes offer a place for these young parents to learn about the basic needs of a child. While, the practicum classes offer a hands on experience caring for the children in the childcare center. Statistics show that less than 10% of teen parents earn their high school diploma by their eighteenth birthday.{{Cite web|url = http://www.socialworktoday.com/archive/031912p24.shtml|title = Keep Teen Mom's In School- A School Social Work|last = Van Pelt|first = Jennifer|date = March–April 2012|website = Social Work Today|publisher =|access-date = March 4, 2016}} These programs are trying to change those statistics. Currently (2016), San Diego County has 7 high schools that offer these teen parent programs. == Prevention == The United States has the highest rates of teenage pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases in developed countries.{{Cite journal|last=Stanger-Hall|first=Kathrin F.|last2=Hall|first2=David W.|date=2011-10-14|title=Abstinence-Only Education and Teen Pregnancy Rates: Why We Need Comprehensive Sex Education in the U.S|url=http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0024658|journal=PLOS ONE|volume=6|issue=10|pages=e24658|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0024658|issn=1932-6203|pmc=3194801|pmid=22022362}} The two primary reasons given by teenagers for not using protection is that the chance of becoming pregnant is small, and the failure to anticipate intercourse.{{Cite journal|last=Trussell|first=James|date=Spring 2017|title=Teenage Pregnancy in the United States|url=|journal=Family Planning Perspectives|volume=6|pages=|doi=10.2307/2135482}} Teen pregnancies can be prevented. The best method of reducing the consequences of teenage parenthood is by providing reproductive health services to prevent teenagers from becoming pregnant in the first place. Prevention can not only be beneficial on a micro level but it is also beneficial on a more macro scale. Nationally, teen pregnancies cost tax payers an average of $9.4 billion each year. These costs are associated with health care, foster care, criminal justice, public assistance and lost tax revenue. Teen pregnancies can be prevented by increasing access and education on the proper use of contraceptives, as well as parental involvement. The best method of prevention is to integrate sex and STD education into the middle and high school science curriculum as well as addressing the effects of teenage pregnancies in the social studies curriculum. == International comparison == {{Main|Prevalence of teenage pregnancy}} [[File:Teenage birth rate per 1000 women 15–19, 2000-09.svg|thumb|450px|The teenage birth rate per 1,000 women aged 15–19, 2000–2009.[http://unstats.un.org/unsd/demographic/products/dyb/dyb2009-2010/Table10.pdf Live births by age of mother and sex of child bred, general and age-specific fertility rates: latest available year, 2000–2009] — United Nations Statistics Division – Demographic and Social Statistics]] There are large differences in adolescent pregnancy rates among developed nations like Canada, France, Great Britain, Sweden and the United States. The United States has the highest number of teen pregnancies and the highest number of STD’s compared to the other four countries. In France and Sweden during the late '90s, pregnancies were 20 per 1,000 women at ages 15–19.{{cite web|last1=Darroch|first1=Jacqueline|last2=Singh|first2=Susheela|last3=Frost|first3=Jennifer|title=Differences in Teenage Pregnancy Rates Among Five Developed Countries: The Roles of Sexual Activity and Contraceptive Use|url=https://www.guttmacher.org/journals/psrh/2001/11/differences-teenage-pregnancy-rates-among-five-developed-countries-roles}} In Canada and Great Britain the levels were twice that, and the United States the level was 4 times as high with 84 per 1,000 teenage women pregnant. The likelihood of pregnant teenage girls having abortions across the four countries differ and exclude miscarriages. In the U.S. abortion rates for 15–19 years are 35% while in Sweden it was 69%. Leaving Great Britain with 39%, Canada with 46% and France with 51%.{{cite web|last1=Darroch|first1=Jacqueline|last2=Singh|first2=Susheela|last3=Frost|first3=Jennifer|title=Differences in Teenage Pregnancy Rates Among Five Developed Countries: The Roles of Sexual Activity and Contraceptive Use|url=https://www.guttmacher.org/journals/psrh/2001/11/differences-teenage-pregnancy-rates-among-five-developed-countries-roles}} It has been suggested that the U.S. teen pregnancy rate is higher because of the prevalence of abstinence-only sex education. As a result, these adolescents are not fully aware of how to respond to sexual activity if it comes their way. The mentality of some education systems in the U.S. have the idea that if they do not teach safe sex, adolescents will refrain from sex{{Citation needed|reason=This reads like the author's conjecture/opinion, not an established fact. Overly conversational tone, citation reeded|date=July 2017}}. As the data concludes from above that compared to the other developed countries the U.S. is four times as likely to have a teen pregnancy. Yet the U.S. also uses less contraceptive, has more abortions{{Citation needed|reason=Citation needed for claim that the US has more abortions than "the other developed countries"|date=July 2017}} and more prevalence of sexually transmitted diseases than the other developed countries. In the U.S. all states are involved in sex education, but each state has differences in what they teach. Some states choose to go in detail others just cover the bases. Which include 39 states that require “some” education related to sexuality. There are 21 states that are required by law to teach sexuality and STD education. 17 states only require the teaching of STDs and not sexual education. There are also 11 states that have no requirement and leave it up to that state to decide whether or not they teach sex education.{{cite web|title=Sex and HIV Education|url=https://www.guttmacher.org/state-policy/explore/sex-and-hiv-education}} == Modern decline == Although there is a noticeable decline in U.S. teen pregnancy, the current rate is still 2-4 times more than in Canada, France, Great Britain, and Sweden. The biggest difference in the rate of pregnancies in the United States compared to the other countries is that in America there is a very high unintended pregnancy rate. This unintended pregnancy rate is higher than the total teenage pregnancy rate in all of the four countries. {{cite web|last1=Darroch|first1=Jacqueline|last2=Singh|first2=Susheela|last3=Frost|first3=Jennifer|title=Differences in Teenage Pregnancy Rates Among Five Developed Countries: The Roles of Sexual Activity and Contraceptive Use|url=https://www.guttmacher.org/journals/psrh/2001/11/differences-teenage-pregnancy-rates-among-five-developed-countries-roles|website=Guttmacher Institute}} In 2010 there was a rate of 57 pregnancies per 1,000 women aged 15–19. Most of those women reported that it was an unplanned pregnancy. This shows a 15% drop in pregnancies from 2008 to 2010. There is a huge decline in adolescent pregnancy for the nation as a whole. The cause of these declines are from abstaining from sex or better use of contraceptives.{{cite web|last1=Boonstra|first1=Heather|title=What Is Behind the Declines in Teen Pregnancy Rates?|url=https://www.guttmacher.org/gpr/20what-behind-declines-teen-pregnancy-rates|website=Guttmacher Institute}} Birth rates among younger teens ages 15–17 have also fallen faster – dropping by 50%, compared with a 39% decline among older teens ages 18 and 19.{{cite web |last1=Patten |first1=Eileen |author2=Gretchen Livingston |title=Why is the teen birth rate falling? |url=http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2016/04/29/why-is-the-teen-birth-rate-falling/ |publisher=Pew Research Center |date= 29 April 2016 |accessdate=3 May 2017}} Researchers have concluded that these declines stem from improvement in use of contraceptives. ==See also== * [[Minors and abortion#United States]] * [[Native Americans and reservation inequality#Teenage pregnancy]] * [[Prevalence of teenage pregnancy in the United States]] ==References== {{reflist|30em|refs= UNICEF. (2001). {{cite web |url= http://www.unicef-icdc.org/publications/pdf/repcard3e.pdf |title= A League Table of Teenage Births in Rich Nations |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20060629123124/http://www.unicef-icdc.org/publications/pdf/repcard3e.pdf |archivedate= June 29, 2006 |df= mdy-all }} {{small|(888 KB)}}. Retrieved July 7, 2006. {{cite journal|vauthors=Singh S, Darroch JE|url=http://www.guttmacher.org/pubs/journals/3201400.html | title=Adolescent Pregnancy and childbearing levels and trends in developed countries |journal=Family Planning Perspectives |year=2000 |volume=32 |issue=1 |pages=14–23|doi=10.2307/2648144|pmid=10710702|jstor=2648144}} {{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204517204577044502583461944?mod=googlenews_wsj|title=Birth Rate Continues to Slide Among Teens|accessdate=March 7, 2012|publisher=Wall Street Journal|year=2011|author=Timothy W. Martin}} [http://globalis.gvu.unu.edu/indicator.cfm?Country=GB&IndicatorID=127 Indicator: Births per 1000 women (15–19 ys) – 2002] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110529091618/http://globalis.gvu.unu.edu/indicator.cfm?Country=GB&IndicatorID=127 |date=May 29, 2011 }} UNFPA, State of World Population 2003. Retrieved January 22, 2007. {{cite web |url = http://www.guttmacher.org/pubs/FB-ATSRH.pdf |title = www.guttmacher.org |date = June 2013 |publisher = [[Guttmacher Institute]] |accessdate = August 14, 2013}} {{cite web|url=http://www.thenationalcampaign.org/policymakers/PDF/Briefly_PolicyBrief_RacialEthnicDisparities.pdf|title=Policy Brief: Racial and Ethnic Disparities in Teen Pregnancy|accessdate=October 13, 2008|publisher=The National Campaign to Prevent Teen and Unplanned Pregnancy|date=July 2008|format=PDF|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081029001746/http://www.thenationalcampaign.org/policymakers/PDF/Briefly_PolicyBrief_RacialEthnicDisparities.pdf|archivedate=October 29, 2008|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}} {{cite web|url=http://apps.who.int/whosis/database/core/core_select.cfm|title=Core Health Indicators|accessdate=March 7, 2012|publisher=World Health Organization|year=2008 }} }} ==Further reading== * {{cite book |last1=Ventura |first1=Stephanie J., Brady E. Mathews. |chapter=Pregnancy and childbirth among females aged 10–19 years—United States, 2007-2010 |chapterurl=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/su6203a12.htm?s_cid=su6203a12_w |work=Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report |title=CDC Health Disparities and Inequalities Report—United States, 2013 |year=2013 |volume=62 |issue=33 |pages=71–76}} ==External links== {{Sexual ethics}} {{United States topics}} {{Sex}} {{Reproductive health}} {{North America topic|Teenage pregnancy in}} {{Americas topic|Teenage pregnancy in}} [[Category:Teenage pregnancy|United States]] [[Category:Adolescent sexuality in the United States]] [[Category:Maternity in the United States]] [[Category:American culture]]

The [[Telegram (service)|Telegram]] [[Instant messaging|instant messaging service]] has more than 50 million users in Iran<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-43907246 Iran blocks video and images on Telegram messaging app - BBC.com]</ref> and 60% of the country's Internet's bandwidth is spent on using this app.<ref name="ایسنا 2017">{{cite web | title=تلگرام ۶۰ درصد پهنای باند کشور را اشغال کرد | website=ایسنا | date=September 18, 2017 | url=https://www.isna.ir/news/96062715757/تلگرام-۶۰-درصد-پهنای-باند-کشور-را-اشغال-کرد | language=fa | access-date=June 6, 2018}}</ref>
Following the disruptions caused by the Iranian government in the [[Viber]]<ref name="خبرگزاری فارس 2015">{{cite web | title=موج مهاجرت کاربران تلفن همراه از وایبر به تلگرام/ فرصت مغتنم برای پیام‌رسان‌های ایرانی | website=خبرگزاری فارس | date=May 5, 2015 | url=http://www.farsnews.com/news/13940215000378 | language=fa | access-date=June 6, 2018}}</ref><ref name="انتخاب 2014">{{cite web | last=انتخاب | first=پایگاه خبری تحلیلی | title=وایبر هم بالاخره فیلتر شد | website=پایگاه خبری تحلیلی انتخاب | Entekhab.ir | date=May 14, 2014 | url=http://www.entekhab.ir/fa/news/161368 | language=fa | access-date=June 6, 2018}}</ref> and [[Line (software)|Line]] services, the Iranian people were attracted to Telegram.<ref name="تبیان 2017">{{cite web | last=تبیان | first=موسسه فرهنگی و اطلاع‌رسانی | title=از وایبر به تلگرام | website=سایت مؤسسه فرهنگی و اطلاع‌رسانی تبیان | date=February 21, 2017 | url=https://article.tebyan.net/296339/از-وایبر-به-تلگرام | language=fa | access-date=June 6, 2018}}</ref> Security was the most important reason that led to this immigration. Additionally, this service permitted exchanging files up to 1 gigabyte.<ref name="آی تی رسان 2015">{{cite web | title=آی تی رسان | website=آی تی رسان | date=June 29, 2015 | url=https://itresan.com/ | language=fa | access-date=June 6, 2018}}</ref><ref name="ایسنا">{{cite web | title=جنگ وایبر با تلگرام | website=ایسنا | url=https://www.isna.ir/news/96071708740/جنگ-وایبر-با-تلگرام | language=fa | access-date=June 6, 2018}}</ref>
[[The Islamic Republic of Iran]] has repeatedly considered the topic of blocking access to Telegram and has always imposed limitations on users' access. During the [[2017–18 Iranian protests|protests on December 8, 2017]], Telegram was blocked for more than a week and finally became available again on December 23, 2017.<ref name="آخرین خبر | در کوتاهترین زمان بروزترین باشید 2018">{{cite web | title=آخرین خبر - تلگرام مختل شد یا فیلتر؟ | website=آخرین خبر | در کوتاهترین زمان بروزترین باشید | date=June 6, 2018 | url=http://akharinkhabar.com/Pages/News.aspx?id=2181875 | language=fa | access-date=June 6, 2018}}</ref><ref name="زومیت 2015">{{cite web | title=مدیر عامل تلگرام: ایران از چهارشنبه دسترسی به تلگرام را محدود کرده است [بروزرسانی: پاسخ وزارت ارتباطات] | website=زومیت | date=October 21, 2015 | url=http://www.zoomit.ir/it-news/internet-network/25217-telegram-banned-iran | language=fa | access-date=June 6, 2018}}</ref><ref name="ايران 1 2018">{{cite web | last=ايران | first=عصر | title=5 نکته درباره شایعه فیلترینگ "تلگرام" | website=عصر ايران | date=June 6, 2018 | url=http://www.asriran.com/fa/news/425508 | language=fa | access-date=June 6, 2018}}</ref> It was reblocked on May 10, 2017 by judicial authorities. In the judicial order of the Tehran Prosecutor's Office, it was said that Telegram must be blocked by [[internet service provider|ISPs]] in such a way that it could not be achieved even with tools similar to [[VPN]]s.<ref name="خبرگزاری 2باشگاه خبرنگاران 2018">{{cite web | author=خبرگزاری باشگاه خبرنگاران | title=پایان کار تلگرام در ایران اعلام شد | website=خبرگزاری باشگاه خبرنگاران | آخرین اخبار ایران و جهان | YJC | date=April 30, 2018 | url=http://www.yjc.ir/fa/news/6518604 | language=fa | access-date=June 6, 2018}}</ref>
The two-time experience of blocking Telegram in Iran shows that Iranian users did not migrate to alternative services, such as the foreign [[WhatsApp]], or the domestic [[Soroush messenger]], but resorted to [[Internet censorship circumvention]].<ref name="Khodabakhshi 2018">{{cite web | last=Khodabakhshi | first=Leyla | title=کاربران ایرانی بعد از فیلتر شدن تلگرام چه می‌کنند؟ | website=BBC Persian | date=May 3, 2018 | url=http://www.bbc.com/persian/iran-43995921 | language=fa | access-date=June 6, 2018}}</ref>
==Spying request== On 20 October 2015, [[Paul Durov]], [[CEO]] of Telegram LLC said, after denying the request of Iranian authorities for private information about citizens of the country, Telegram was blocked for hours in [[Iran]], but it was unblocked afterwards.<ref name="BBC Persian 2015">{{cite web | title=تلگرام 'پس از عدم همکاری با دولت ایران موقتا مسدود شد' | website=BBC Persian | date=October 20, 2015 | url=http://www.bbc.com/persian/iran/2015/10/151019_u04_telegram_iran | language=fa | access-date=June 6, 2018}}</ref> Pavel Durov wrote an answer letter and announced that "Iranian authorities want to use Telegram to spy on their citizens. We can not help them in this regard."<ref name="BBC Persian 2015" />
==Blocking== [[File:Countries where Telegram is blocked.svg|thumb|300px|right|Map of countries in which Telegram is completely blocked or partially{{legend|#8E0000|Completely blocked|border=1px #555 solid}} {{legend|#D34343|Blocked partially (some ISPs or audio traffic)|border=1px #555 solid}}]]{{Incomplete section|date=July 2018}}
Following the Iranian government policy to censor every [[social network]] and instant messaging service in Iran, they have continued to disrupt access to Telegram. On Saturday, 19 May 2015, the telecommunication company of Iran blocked Telegram access in some parts of the [[Tehran province]] and some other provinces without prior notice.<ref name="ITIRAN 2018">{{cite web | title=تلگرام در آستانه فیلترشدن؟ | website=ITIRAN | date=May 1, 2018 | url=http://itiran.com/d/68654 | language=fa | access-date=June 6, 2018}}</ref><ref name="انتخاب 2015">{{cite web | last=انتخاب | first=پایگاه خبری تحلیلی | title=مخابرات تلگرام را مسدود کرد | website=پایگاه خبری تحلیلی انتخاب | Entekhab.ir | date=May 10, 2015 | url=http://www.entekhab.ir/fa/news/203390 | language=fa | access-date=June 6, 2018}}</ref>
Only one day after Telegram introduced the voice call feature in the messenger, the voice call functionality was completely blocked in Iran.<ref name="خبرگزاری 3 باشگاه خبرنگاران 2017">{{cite web | author=خبرگزاری باشگاه خبرنگاران | title=دلیل فیلترشدن تماس صوتی تلگرام در ایران | website=خبرگزاری باشگاه خبرنگاران | آخرین اخبار ایران و جهان | YJC | date=April 17, 2017 | url=http://www.yjc.ir/fa/news/6051361 | language=fa | access-date=June 6, 2018}}</ref> Paul Durov wrote in response to users who had asked about voice calls problems in Iran: "Internet service providers in Iran have blocked it again."<ref name="خبرگزاری 1 باشگاه خبرنگاران 2017">{{cite web | author=خبرگزاری باشگاه خبرنگاران | title=دلیل فیلترشدن تماس صوتی تلگرام در ایران | website=خبرگزاری باشگاه خبرنگاران | آخرین اخبار ایران و جهان | YJC | date=April 17, 2017 | url=http://www.yjc.ir/fa/news/6051361 | language=fa | access-date=June 6, 2018}}</ref><ref name="Twitter 2018">{{cite web | title=Pavel Durov on Twitter | website=Twitter | date=May 24, 2018 | url=https://twitter.com/durov/status/854700486989107200 | language=la | access-date=June 6, 2018}}</ref> The low cost of calling using this feature and the subsequent financial losses incurred by the telecommunication network operators, including the stated-owned [[Mobile Telecommunication Company of Iran]], may have motivated the block,<ref name="خبرگزاری باشگاه خبرنگاران 2017">{{cite web | author=خبرگزاری باشگاه خبرنگاران | title=مکالمه صوتی تلگرام به صورت کامل مسدود شد + دلیل مسدود سازی | website=خبرگزاری باشگاه خبرنگاران | آخرین اخبار ایران و جهان | YJC | date=April 17, 2017 | url=http://www.yjc.ir/fa/news/6050736 | language=fa | access-date=June 6, 2018}}</ref> Although public relations of [[MTN Irancell]] announced that the operator has played no role in the disruption of the service.<ref name="ايران 2018">{{cite web | last=ايران | first=عصر | title=تماس صوتی تلگرام نیامده فیلتر شد؟! | website=عصر ايران | date=June 6, 2018 | url=http://www.asriran.com/fa/news/533724 | language=fa | access-date=June 6, 2018}}</ref>
Following the [[2017–18 Iranian protests|nationwide protests in Iran]] in 2017 and 2018, and to prevent rioting, the [[Supreme National Security Council|Supreme National Security Council of Iran]] decided to cut off all [[social network]]s, including Telegram,<ref name="خبرگزاری ایلنا 2018">{{cite web | title=تلگرام فیلتر شده است؟/طبیعی است که دست به محدودیت بزنیم | website=خبرگزاری ایلنا | date=June 6, 2018 | url=https://www.ilnanews.com/بخش-%D9%81%D8%B1%D9%87%D9%86%DA%AF-%D9%87%D9%86%D8%B1-6/577062-%D8%AA%D9%84%DA%AF%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%85-%D9%81%DB%8C%D9%84%D8%AA%D8%B1-%D8%B4%D8%AF%D9%87-%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%AA-%D8%B7%D8%A8%DB%8C%D8%B9%DB%8C-%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%AA-%DA%A9%D9%87-%D8%AF%D8%B3%D8%AA-%D8%A8%D9%87-%D9%85%D8%AD%D8%AF%D9%88%D8%AF%DB%8C%D8%AA-%D8%A8%D8%B2%D9%86%DB%8C%D9%85 | language=fa | access-date=June 6, 2018}}</ref> although it was said to be temporary.<ref name="خبرگزاری ایلنا12 2018">{{cite web | title=فیلتر تلگرام موقتی است | website=خبرگزاری ایلنا | date=June 6, 2018 | url=https://www.ilnanews.com/بخش-%D8%B3%DB%8C%D8%A7%D8%B3%DB%8C-3/577484-%D9%81%DB%8C%D9%84%D8%AA%D8%B1-%D8%AA%D9%84%DA%AF%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%85-%D9%85%D9%88%D9%82%D8%AA%DB%8C-%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%AA | language=fa | access-date=June 6, 2018}}</ref> On the night of January 23, 2017, the block was lifted.<ref name="روزنامک 2018">{{cite web | title=بازتاب جهانی رفع فیلتر تلگرام - روزنامک | website=روزنامک | date=January 14, 2018 | url=http://www.rouznamak.ir/2018/01/%d8%a8%d8%a7%d8%b2%d8%aa%d8%a7%d8%a8-%d8%ac%d9%87%d8%a7%d9%86%db%8c-%d8%b1%d9%81%d8%b9-%d9%81%db%8c%d9%84%d8%aa%d8%b1-%d8%aa%d9%84%da%af%d8%b1%d8%a7%d9%85/ | language=fa | access-date=June 6, 2018}}</ref><ref name="euronews 2018">{{cite web | title=پیام‌رسان تلگرام در ایران رفع فیلتر شد | website=euronews | date=January 13, 2018 | url=http://fa.euronews.com/2018/01/13/iran-relived-telegram-messanger-ban | language=ar | access-date=June 6, 2018}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Internet censorship in Iran]] *[[Internet censorship]] *[[Blocking Telegram in Russia]]

'''Tingal''' is an ethnic group in [[Northern Sudan]]. They speak [[Tingal language|Tingal]], a [[Niger–Congo language]]. They number at least several thousands.
==References== *[https://joshuaproject.net/people_groups/15496/SU Joshua Project]
