[[File:Guldservis från 1777-1778 - Livrustkammaren - 13600.tif|thumb|Silver-gilt service made in London in 1777–78 for the Swedish royal family]] [[File:Kazimierz Dolny July 2013 042.JPG|thumb|A toilet service in silver]]
A '''toilet service''' is a set of objects for use at the [[Lowboy|dressing table]]. The term is usually reserved for large luxury sets from the 17th to 19th centuries, with "toilet set" used for later or simpler sets. Historically, services were made in metal, ceramics, and other materials, for both men and women, though male versions were generally much smaller. The rich had services in gold, silver, or [[silver-gilt]]. The contents vary, but typically include a mirror, one or more small [[ewer]]s and basins, two candlesticks, and an assortment of bowls, boxes, caskets, and other containers.<ref>MOS</ref> One or more brushes and a pin-cushion, often as a top to a box, are often included. The sets usually came with a custom-made travelling case, and some services were especially designed for travelling.
The toilet service was the most important item of "dressing plate", as opposed to table plate, and was often a gift upon marriage;<ref>Glanville, 76, 98</ref> sometimes augmented on the birth of children.<ref>Louvre</ref> It was normally the personal property of the wife. The morning [[Levée (ceremony)|levée]] was sometimes a semi-public occasion for great persons in the [[early modern period]], and the toilet service might be seen by many people.<ref>Glory, 7–8; Adlin, 5–7. Adlin gives [[Madame de Pompadour]] much of the credit for this, but for example Hogarth's ''[[Marriage à-la-mode: 4. The Toilette]]'' is from 1743, before she became at all notable at court. See also [http://www.louvre.fr/en/oeuvre-notices/washbowl-bearing-arms-duchess-orleans-legitimate-daughter-louis-xiv-and-madame-de-mon the Louvre "washbowl" page].</ref>
The word [[toilet]] comes from the French ''toile'' meaning cloth, and ''toilette'' ("little cloth") first came to mean the morning routine of washing, tidying hair, and shaving and making up as appropriate, from the cloth often spread on the dressing-table where this was done. This meaning spread into English as "toilet" in the 17th century; only later did "toilet" start to compete with "lavatory" as a [[euphemism]]. The [[Oxford English Dictionary]] records "toilet" in English first, from 1540, as a term for a cloth used to wrap clothes in, then from 1662 (by [[John Evelyn]]) for a gold toilet service, and before 1700 for a range of related meanings (a towel, the cloth on a dressing-table, the act of using a dressing-table, and so on), but not for a lavatory, which did not come into use until the 19th century.<ref>[[OED]], "Toilet"</ref>
==Contents== [[File:Johan Zoffany - Queen Charlotte (1744-1818) with her Two Eldest Sons - Google Art Project (cropped).jpg|thumb|left|Detail of ''Queen Charlotte with her Two Eldest Sons'', [[Johan Zoffany]], 1765, ([[:File:Johan Zoffany - Queen Charlotte (1744-1818) with her Two Eldest Sons - Google Art Project.jpg|the whole painting]])]] The contents of a service were variable but the classical grouping had as its largest piece the mirror, usually decorated at the top with some form of crest. In the 17th century these were rectangular, usually oblongs in "portrait" format, though the Louvre mirror and the Lennoxlove service use a "landscape" format. The frame normally had a wooden framework holding the glass, over which the metal was fitted.<ref>Louvre; MOS</ref> In the 18th century oval mirrors began to be used, and later the introduction of dressing tables with built-in mirrors was part of the decline from fashion of the toilet service. Depictions in art, such as the Zoffany of [[Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz|Queen Charlotte]], wife of George III, usually show that the elaborate crest at the top of the mirror has disappeared beneath the lace covers spreading to the sides, which are probably tied round it. These were used to pull over the service on its table when it was not in use, or when husbands or other inconvenient visitors appeared in the dressing room.<ref>Schroder</ref>
The service usually contained two fairly small candlesticks, allowing the face to be lit from below. There may also be "hand-candles", "chamber candles" or "chamber sticks", short, with a wide saucer-like base and a loop or handle. These were the last lights to be put out at night, and were carried in the hand.<ref>Taylor, 209</ref> Candlestick makers (who always used [[casting]]) were treated as a speciality within silversmithing, and the candlesticks may be made by different workshops from the other pieces, as may any snuffers, also regarded as a speciality.<ref>Glanville, 99; MOS</ref> [[File:Marriage A-la-Mode 4, The Toilette - William Hogarth (cropped).jpg|thumb|Detail of [[William Hogarth]]'s ''[[Marriage à-la-mode: 4. The Toilette]]'', 1743]]
The service often contains one or a pair of ewer and basin sets for washing. There is normally a number of other vessels of various sizes and shapes, some covered and others not, which go by a great variety of names, and whose purpose was perhaps always rather undefined. A variety of brushes might be included, and sometimes a small bell. In the 18th century glass and porcelain items might be mixed in with the silver ones. Services also might contain food plates and cutlery (usually just for one) for breakfast or snacks in the bedroom or dressing-room, or when travelling. One large type of bowl is connected with oatmeal, though it seems this might either be made into a facial, or eaten as [[porridge]] (or both, with a pair).<ref>Glanville, 99; Louvre; MOS; Glory, 7–8; Taylor, 159-160</ref> Descriptions include items such as comb-boxes, glove-trays, soap-boxes, low [[tazze]] (or "waiters"), salvers, [[ecuelle]]s (small bowls with two handles) and others. The 48-piece German Schenk von Stauffenberg service (1740s, now [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]) contains several items for food and drink, including a [[teapot]], and also items for writing, such as an [[inkstand]].<ref>[http://www.metmuseum.org/collection/the-collection-online/search?ft=Schenk+von+Stauffenberg Schenk von Stauffenberg service], German, 1740s, Metropolitan Museum of Art; [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=G-akfb80yFEC&pg=PA55 ''Philippe de Montebello and the Metropolitan Museum of Art: 1977–2008'', p. 55], James R. Houghton, Metropolitan Museum of Art (New York, N.Y.)</ref>
The male service was much simpler, typically consisting of a shaving-bowl (oval, with a crescent cut out at one side), ewer and basin, a soap-box, toothbrush holder, perhaps a tongue-scraper and some boxes and bowls.<ref>Glanville, 98; Bennion, 294–302; Glory, 122</ref> These started later, in the 18th-century, when men began to shave themselves, or have a servant do it, rather than requiring a quasi-medical [[barber surgeon]] specialist.<ref>Adlin, 10, 30–31</ref> [[File:Lady at Her Toilet - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|A Dutch lady at her toilet, 1650s]] [[File:Toilet Service at Weston Park, Staffs DSCF1061 08.jpg|thumb|Top of the [[Weston Park]] mirror, 1679]]
In ''Mundus Muliebris'', a satire on fashionable ladies published in 1700, by [[Mary Evelyn]], the daughter of [[John Evelyn]] (or by him, or both of them),<ref>Sources disagree</ref> the toilet service was described. Although by no means an insider at court, Evelyn was able to see the queen's toilet service and his diary records his admiring comments.<ref>Taylor, 159</ref> In the poem:
<poem>:A new Scene to us next presents, :The Dressing-Room, and Implements, :Of Toilet Plate Gilt, and Emboss'd, :And several other things of Cost: :The Table Miroir, one Glue Pot, :One for Pomatum, and what not? :Of Washes, Unguents, and Cosmeticks, :A pair of Silver Candlesticks; :Snuffers, and Snuff-dish, Boxes more, :For Powders, Patches, Waters store, :In silver Flasks or Bottles, Cups :Cover'd, or open to wash Chaps;...<ref>[http://womenwriters.library.emory.edu/content.php?level=div&id=evelyn_003&document=evelyn Emory Women Writers Resource Project, ''Mundus Muliebris: Or, The Ladies Dressing-Room Unlock'd, and her Toilette Spread''], an electronic edition</ref></poem>
In the 18th-century special dressing-tables with a fitted mirror began to be made, so removing the need for the traditional centrepiece of a service.<ref>Adlin, 5–9, 24–25</ref> Men also had special shaving tables, often on long legs for shaving standing up.<ref>Adlin, 10, 30–31</ref>
The full toilette did not always occur at the start of the day, but might be before going out or having a formal meal. In the Zoffany portrait of Queen Charlotte above: "... Father Time appears scythe-bearing on the clock, but the face reads exactly 2.30pm, which means that the Princes have finished their dinner (which since November 1764 they had taken at 2.00pm) and are visiting their mother, after she has dressed (a process which began at 1.00pm), while their governess waits in the room beyond. The Queen will dine with the King at exactly 4.00pm."<ref>"Text adapted from ''The Conversation Piece: Scenes of fashionable life'', London, 2009", at [http://www.royalcollection.org.uk/collection/search#/1/collection/400146/queen-charlotte-1744-1818-with-her-two-eldest-sons "Johan Joseph Zoffany (Frankfurt 1733-London 1810), Queen Charlotte (1744–1818) with her Two Eldest Sons c.1765"] on the Royal Collection website.</ref>
===Packing a German service of 1743-45 (Metropolitan Museum of Art)=== <gallery widths="200px" heights="200px" perrow="4"> File:Toilet set in original leather case MET DP137849 (cropped).jpg|The set is mostly in silver-gilt, but includes two Japanese [[Imari ware]] teacups File:Toilet set in original leather case MET DP137847.jpg|Various [[Augsburg]] goldsmiths made pieces File:Toilet set in original leather case MET DP137845.jpg|Next a padded cloth protects the mirror File:Toilet set in original leather case MET DP137842.jpg|The case is leather over a wood frame </gallery>
==History and style== [[File:NMoS Toilet service (cropped).jpg|thumb|The [[Lennoxlove]] toilet service in silver-gilt; its travelling chest on the other side of the case<ref>MOS</ref>]] [[File:1695 Tobias Baurs Reiseservice mit Koffer anagoria.JPG|thumb|German travelling toilet service, 1695]]
Earlier examples of the component pieces existed, as is clear from documentary records and stray surviving pieces, but the toilet service as a large matching set of pieces seems to become common among the rich in the 17th century, and especially the France of [[Louis XIV]]. Sets of ewers and basins such as the [[Lomellini Ewer and Basin]] were a staple of display plate well before this, but the many paintings of the ''Toilet of Venus'', for example by [[Rubens]], show that until about 1650 even goddesses used mirrors with wooden frames. Although many were made, very few Louis XIV toilet services survive, and these are all ones that left France quickly, and escaped the very effective drives at the end of Louis's reign to get the nobility to donate their plate to help pay for the ruinous [[Nine Years' War]] and [[War of the Spanish Succession]]. Exiled [[Huguenot]] silversmiths helped to spread French styles in England and elsewhere.<ref>MOS</ref> Once established, the characteristic types of pieces changed little, but their style followed general fashions in the decorative arts.<ref>Glanville, 99</ref>
Heraldic decoration with the [[coat of arms]] of the owner was very common. This could be engraved, or on small cast pieces attached to the main vessel by bolts. This method made it easier to change the heraldry if a service changed hands to a different family, and is used on the Lennoxlove and other services.<ref>MOS; Glanville, 202-04</ref> It is clear that many services were mainly made up from standard designs, perhaps often available from a silversmith's stock, and often built up taking some individual pieces from other silversmiths working with the same designs. Moulds were also lent between workshops.<ref>Glanville, 99; Snodin, 125</ref> In the 18th century [[pattern book]]s became important, initially mostly French, but later originating in England and other countries; these supplemented earlier drawings and individual prints. The sophisticated and complicated designs of the [[Rococo]] accelerated this process.<ref>MOS; Snodin, 28-32, 122-125</ref>
Except for heraldic animals, [[putti]] and decorative masks, figurative decoration was relatively unusual until the advent of porcelain or enamel in the 18th century, but a group of English services of the 1680s use the same [[plaquette]] designs, of uncertain origin, on the tops of round and rectangular boxes, as well as elaborate cast and chased decoration of foliage and putti. These are a service (London 1683) once in the collection of [[J.P. Morgan]], now in the [[Al Tajir]] collection, the Calverly service in the Victoria and Albert Museum, and another.<ref>Glory, 60–61; Expert, 7</ref> The English [[Lionel Sackville, 1st Duke of Dorset|Sackville]] service of about 1750 ([[Museum of Fine Arts, Boston]]) has several pieces decorated with scenes of lovers in landscapes.<ref>[http://www.mfa.org/collections/object/14-piece-toilet-service-271999 The Sackville service], about 1750, [[Museum of Fine Arts, Boston]]</ref> [[File:Nécessaire de voyage (8273755837).jpg|thumb|''Nécessaire de voyage'', given by Napoleon I to his Empress, Paris, 1810]]
A few services survive in the very different technique of Asian [[filigree]], with scrolling filigree decoration applied to plain silver beneath, or left as [[openwork]]. These are concentrated in the [[Hermitage Museum]] and [[Burghley House]] in England. They appear to come from China, and India in the case of one of the Hermitage services.<ref>[http://www.artwis.com/articles/silver-wonders-from-the-east/2/ the Hermitage services], [http://www.burghley.co.uk/collections/collection/a-silver-filigree-toilet-service/ Burghley House service known as "Queen Elizabeth's toilet service"], [http://www.christies.com/lotfinder/LotDetailsPrintable.aspx?intObjectID=925897 Chistie's lot details]</ref>
In the 18th century services continued to be made, with both the Rococo and [[Neoclassicism|Neoclassical]] styles lending themselves well to dressing plate. By the mid-century the large service was falling somewhat out of fashion, and fewer were made. The depiction of the toilette in [[William Hogarth]]'s ''[[Marriage à-la-mode: 4. The Toilette]]'' (1743), with a mirror larger than in any surviving example, is disapproving,<ref>Schroder; Adlin, 9</ref> and one of many satirical accounts and caricatures.<ref>Adlin, 9–10</ref> At the same time the development of dressing tables with integral mirrors, and porcelain vessels, represented an alternative style of toilet equipment. The silver-gilt Neoclassical service made in London in 1779, now in Sweden (illustrated at top) is a late English example, and [[Philippa Glanville]] describes the Zoffany portrait of Queen Charlotte as showing "almost the latest flourish of the silver toilet service",<ref>Glanville, 100, quoted</ref> although George III gave her another service a few years later.<ref>Expert, 9</ref>
Older services continued to be in demand, and the [[provenance]] of several surviving examples shows them being bought and sold, presumably for continued use (see the Shireburn/Norfolk service below). Several services were created from pieces by several different makers from a range of years, as can be seen from their [[hallmark]]s; for example the Lennoxlove service contains hallmarks from a period of some 15 years.<ref>MOS; Snodin, 125; Taylor, 211</ref> A service in the [[Royal Collection]] was created in 1824–25 for [[Prince Frederick, Duke of York and Albany|Frederick, Duke of York]], mostly using pieces a century or more old, supplemented by some contemporary ones and a new case.<ref>[http://www.royalcollection.org.uk/collection/search#/1/collection/50478/toilet-service "Edward Farrell, Toilet service, hallmarks 1699–1824"], Royal Collection, RCIN 50478</ref>
==Porcelain== Porcelain services were produced from the 18th century onwards. Initially the grandest examples were hardly less expensive than silver. What was probably [[Madame de Pompadour]]'s [[Manufacture nationale de Sèvres|Sèvres porcelain]] service of 1763 is in the [[Wallace Collection]] in London. She died the following year and the service was probably incomplete and never delivered. Lacking a mirror, it has three pairs of containers and two brushes.<ref>[http://wallacelive.wallacecollection.org/eMuseumPlus?service=ExternalInterface&module=collection&objectId=71965&viewType=detailView Wallace Collection page]</ref> When [[Maria Feodorovna (Sophie Dorothea of Württemberg)|Maria Feodorovna]], wife of the future Tsar [[Paul I of Russia]] visited Paris in 1782 under a thin [[Anonymity|incognito]] as the "Comtesse du Nord", Queen [[Marie Antoinette]] gave her a Sèvres toilet service that cost 75,000 livres, though this included decoration in a complicated technique using gold foil, enamel and jewels.<ref>Sassoon, 102</ref>
Another large service in [[Meissen porcelain]] with gold mounts was given to [[Maria Amalia of Saxony]], Queen of Naples and later of Spain, by her mother [[Maria Josepha of Austria]] in 1747, to celebrate the birth of her son.<ref>Cassidy-Geiger, 237–238; Bonhams lot details, [https://www.bonhams.com/auctions/19483/lot/8/ "A Meissen gold-mounted oval snuff box from the toilet service for Queen Maria Amalia Christina of Naples and Sicily, Princess of Saxony, circa 1745–47"]</ref> A service in [[Vincennes porcelain]] with Parisian gold mounts was apparently intended as a diplomatic gift to [[Constantinople]] in the mid-1750s, but was never completed, perhaps because Franco-Turkish relations deteriorated. A casket survives in the [[Wallace Collection]] in London.<ref>[http://wallacelive.wallacecollection.org/eMuseumPlus?service=direct/1/ResultLightboxView/result.t2.collection_lightbox.$TspTitleLink$0.link&sp=10&sp=Scollection&sp=SfieldValue&sp=0&sp=0&sp=2&sp=Slightbox_3x4&sp=0&sp=Sdetail&sp=0&sp=F&sp=T&sp=1 "Six plaques mounted in a coffer; Plaques 'de coffre' of the second size"], Wallace Collection</ref> [[File:Bathing Kit of Napoléon Bonaparte IMG 1922.JPG|thumb|Shaving and bathing set of [[Napoleon]]]]
[[Queen Victoria]]'s [[Mintons|Minton porcelain]] service, given as a Christmas present by [[Albert, Prince Consort|Prince Albert]] in 1853, remains on display in her dressing-room at [[Osbourne House]].<ref>[http://www.royalcollection.org.uk/collection/search#/15/collection/34627/scent-bottle-holder "Scent-bottle holder, c.1853, RCIN 34627"], Royal Collection website</ref>
[[Battersea enamel]] was also used for toilet items; the [[Royal Collection]] has a set of 7 rectangular "toilet boxes" from c. 1765, painted with pastoral landscapes around Rome.<ref>[http://www.royalcollection.org.uk/collection/search#/2/collection/22385/set-of-toilet-boxes "Set of toilet boxes, circa 1765, Enamel, gilt metal, RCIN 22385]</ref>
==Travelling services== Most services originally had custom travelling cases, as most owners had more than one residence. Some of these survive; the Lennoxlove service was found in its ornate "travelling chest" in the attic of [[Lennoxlove House]] in 1924, having apparently been overlooked as the house had changed hands more than once.<ref>MOS; [http://www.nms.ac.uk/explore/search-our-collections/collection-item/?item_id=370335&search=description=%27lennoxlove%20toilet%20service%27&startfrom=33 The Lennoxlove travelling chest]</ref> The Naples Meissen porcelain service, which had an unusually long way to travel from its maker in [[Dresden]], had an individual leather case for each item.<ref>Cassidy-Geiger, 237–238</ref>
Some services were made with an eye to being compact and easily transportable. The "necessaire" was a term for either a small decorative container for small handy tools such as scissors, tweezers, a spoon, pencil and similar,<ref>Adlin, 27; Glory, 244-45</ref> these also called an [[etui]], or a larger travelling set, originally usually concentrating on small sets of pieces for drinks such as tea and coffee, but later expanded to also include articles for the toilet, writing, sewing, and medicine.<ref>For "medical" and hygienic items, see Bennion, 294–302</ref> The larger cases also became works of art in their own right, with fine inlays in brass. As a frequent traveller, [[Napoleon]] commissioned several of these.<ref>[http://www.royalcollection.org.uk/collection/search#/39/collection/61160/necessaire-case "Martin Guillaume Biennais (1764–1843), Necessaire case, 1810–14"], Royal Collection</ref>
===Gallery of small necessaires and travelling cases=== <gallery widths="200px" heights="200px" perrow="4"> File:English - Toilet Case with Scenes from the "Metamorphoses" - Walters 57953 - Open.jpg|English, c. 1750, [[Etui]] or Toilet Case in gold with Scenes from the "Metamorphoses", "contains a silver-and-gold folding knife, a pair of scissors, a gold bodkin and pencil, a pair of steel tweezers, and an ivory writing tablet". File:German - Heart-Shaped Toilet Case - Walters 57842 - Open.jpg|German, Toilet Case, c. 1750, "contains two glass scent bottles, a mirror, a folding ivory writing tablet, a gold bodkin, two gold toothpicks, and a miniature pair of gold tweezers". File:Miniature dressing-case, Walker Art Gallery.jpg|Miniature dressing-case, 1750-1760, [[Shagreen|sharkskin]] and silver File:English Coromandel Nécessaire.jpg|thumb|English nécessaire de voyage, or toilet set, crafted of coromandel, including cut crystal containers, gilt-handled manicure tools, and elaborately pierced gilt boxes. Hallmarked London, 1884
</gallery>
==Early examples== [[File:Toilet Service at Weston Park, Staffs DSCF1061 13.jpg|thumb|1679 service at [[Weston Park]] ([[Sconce (light fixture)|sconce]]s later)]] [[File:Alexandra Nikolaevna's toilet set (Fasanierie castle) 02 by shako.JPG|thumb|[[Grand Duchess Alexandra Nikolaevna of Russia]]'s toilet service, 1842]]
The surviving piece that goes back closest to the origin of the grand toilet set is the mirror from the service of [[Anne Hyde]], wife of the future [[James II of England]], which was made in Paris in 1660–61, and is now in the [[Louvre]]. This probably drew from the design of the 40 piece service, now lost, given by Louis XIV to [[Anne of Austria]], which is usually taken to be the first of the grand matching services; this may have been in solid gold.<ref>Louvre (also the Louvre "washbowl" page below, for "40 pieces"); Cowen, 79</ref>
Only three marked French toilet services from the reign of Louis XIV survive. [[Chatsworth House]] has a 23 piece service made for Queen [[Mary II of England]], the [[Museum of Scotland]] has the 17 piece Lennoxlove Service, and [[Rosenborg Castle]], [[Copenhagen]] has a 17 piece service owned by a [[Hedvig Sophia of Sweden|Swedish princess]].<ref>MOS</ref> A further unmarked set is now in a museum in [[Toledo, Ohio]];<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1350&dat=19791114&id=3C1PAAAAIBAJ&sjid=kgIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3558,831216&hl=en Toledo Blade – Nov 14, 1979, "Toilet Set Gift to Museum"]</ref> this is "almost identical" to the Lennoxlove service.<ref>MOS</ref>
Some 25 English toilet services from before 1800 survive,<ref>Glanville, 99</ref> about half now abroad; in 2012 an expert report to the official committee granting export licences recorded only 12 English-made metal toilet services in British collections.<ref>Expert, 7–8 (plus the Norfolk service itself)</ref> [[Knole House]] has an English set of 18 pieces made in 1674, the earliest English-made service.<ref>Expert, 7</ref> The 14 pieces in the service at [[Weston Park]] are hallmarked for 1679.<ref>[[:File:Toilet Service at Weston Park, Staffs DSCF1061 20.jpg|Photo of information sheet at the house]]</ref>
One of these, a 34 piece [[silver-gilt]] English toilet service made in 1708, and presented by her father to [[Maria Howard, Duchess of Norfolk]] on her marriage was granted an export license from the UK to Australia in 2012, despite objections by the [[Victoria and Albert Museum]]. Having cost around £700 in 1708, paid in installments, it was sold for £1,380,000 in 2012. It was made by the leading London silversmith Benjamin Pyne in the "plain English" style, as opposed to the French style used by Huguenot makers. It had been bought by the London jewellers [[Rundell, Bridge & Rundell]] as part-exchange for a new dinner service for the Duke of Norfolk in the early 19th century, and they it sold to [[William Lowther, 1st Earl of Lonsdale]], adding his cypher "discreetly".<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=_Jy3WZIuH_YC&pg=PA36 Department for Culture, Media and Sport: Export of Objects of Cultural Interest], 2012/13 Report; Expert, throughout; Glory, 78–79</ref>
The [[Ashmolean Museum]] in Oxford has two significant examples, the Acton toilet service (14 pieces, silver, London, 1699–1700),<ref>[http://www.ashmolean.org/ash/objects/makedetail.php?pmu=129&mu=149&gty=qsea&sec=&dtn=15&sfn=Object,Accession%20Number%28s%29,Material,Marks/Maker,Heraldry&cpa=1&rpos=0&key=Acton Ashmolean page, "The Acton toilet service"]; Expert, 7</ref> and the Treby toilet service (29 pieces, London, [[Paul de Lamerie]], 1724–1725),<ref>[http://www.ashmolean.org/ash/objects/makedetail.php?pmu=129&mu=149&gty=qsea&sec=&dtn=15&sfn=Object,Accession%20Number%28s%29,Material,Marks/Maker,Heraldry&cpa=1&rpos=0&key=Treby Ashmolean page, "The Treby toilet service"]; Expert, 8</ref> for which the bill survives, giving interesting information.<ref>Taylor, 211</ref>
==Museum pages== *The Lennoxlove service in the [[National Museum of Scotland]], Edinburgh, [http://www.nms.ac.uk/explore/collections-stories/art-and-design/lennoxlove-toilet-service/ link], Paris, 1652–72 *[https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O10973/calverley-toilet-service-mirror-frame-fowle-william/ The Calverley service], London, 1683–84, [[Victoria and Albert Museum]]<ref>Taylor, 159-160</ref> *An English service of 1687–88, in the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], New York, [http://www.metmuseum.org/collection/the-collection-online/search/202941?rpp=30&pg=1&rndkey=20150622&ft=*&who=Fowle%2BWilliam%24William%2BFowle&pos=1&imgno=2&tabname=object-information overall picture], including a [http://www.metmuseum.org/collection/the-collection-online/search/202941?rpp=30&pg=1&rndkey=20150622&ft=*&who=Fowle%2BWilliam%24William%2BFowle&pos=1&imgno=0&tabname=object-information mirror], [http://www.metmuseum.org/collection/the-collection-online/search/202950?=&imgno=0&tabname=related-objects pin-cushion] and [http://www.metmuseum.org/collection/the-collection-online/search/202949 two scent bottles],<ref>Adlin, 26</ref> *[[Royal Collection]], [https://www.royalcollection.org.uk/collection/search#/2/collection/50478/toilet-service Edward Farrell and others, hallmarks 1699-1824], in 2016 on display at [[Hampton Court Palace]]? ; [https://www.royalcollection.org.uk/collection/search#/7/collection/43936/travelling-service Martin Guillaume Biennais (1764–1843), Travelling service 1800-15], for Stéphanie de Beauharnais *[http://www.louvre.fr/en/oeuvre-notices/washbowl-bearing-arms-duchess-orleans-legitimate-daughter-louis-xiv-and-madame-de-mon "Washbowl bearing the arms of the Duchess of Orléans, legitimate daughter of Louis XIV and Madame de Montespan"], Paris, 1719–20, Louvre *[http://www.artfund.org/supporting-museums/art-weve-helped-buy/artwork/5550/the-kildare-toilet-service The Kildare Toilet Service by David Willaume], 1722, Art Fund, now in the [[Ulster Museum]] *[http://www.metmuseum.org/collection/the-collection-online/search?ft=Schenk+von+Stauffenberg Schenk von Stauffenberg service], German, 1740s, Metropolitan Museum of Art.<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=G-akfb80yFEC&pg=PA55 ''Philippe de Montebello and the Metropolitan Museum of Art: 1977–2008'', p. 55], James R. Houghton, Metropolitan Museum of Art (New York, N.Y.)</ref> *[http://www.mfa.org/collections/object/14-piece-toilet-service-271999 The Sackville service], about 1750, [[Museum of Fine Arts, Boston]] *The Williams-Wynn service in the [[National Museum of Wales]], Cardiff [https://www.museumwales.ac.uk/art/online/?action=show_item&item=4230 link],<ref>also Snodin, 125</ref> *[http://www.vam.ac.uk/users/node/9251 Silver and [[shagreen]] 5-piece service], John Paul Cooper, 1925-9, Victoria and Albert Museum *[http://www.polamuseum.or.jp/english/collection/006-0037-n034/ 18 Piece Rose-colored Glass Toilet Service], 1940s, [[Pola Museum of Art]], Japan
<gallery widths="200px" heights="200px" perrow="4"> File:Wilhelmina von Hallwyls toilettsilver på byrå i sängkammaren - Hallwylska museet - 4996.tif|Swedish service, 1697 File:François Boucher 008.jpg|A lady receives a sales call from a ''modiste'' selling ribbons, [[François Boucher]], 1746 File:WLA haa Pair of Toilet Figure Candlesticks.jpg|A pair of low toilet candlesticks, [[Derby Porcelain]], c. 1765 File:Johann Jacob Kirstein 001.JPG|Pieces from a 1780 service, (?) [[Strasbourg]] File:250 Chiffonière Paris c1780 01.jpg|Chiffonière dressing table, Paris c. 1780 File:250 Chiffonière Paris c1780 02.jpg|Interior view File:Hygienartiklar i necessär - Livrustkammaren - 64856.tif|Service of [[Victoria of Baden]], [[Queen of Sweden]] from 1907, when this was made File:Brede-LilleBrede-toiletrybox.JPG|A later service in Japanese-style [[lacquerware]]

'''Whyman McLean''' was an Australian Aboriginal man, a religious [[Missionary|missionary]] who later served as an [[Aboriginal tracker]] in the [[New South Wales Police Force|New South Wales Police Force]] for thirty years until his retirement in 1925.
==Early life== Whyman McLean was born at Morago, New South Wales in approximately 1860. He was the son of Archibald McLean and Louisa, an Aboriginal woman.<ref name="Pathfinders">{{cite web|title=Whyman McLean|url=https://pathfindersnsw.org.au/placemarks/whyman-mclean/|website=Pathfinders NSW|accessdate=24 January 2018|language=en}}</ref> As a young man, Whyman lived on the [[Maloga Mission]].
==Career== McLean worked for many years as a missionary, travelling to Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne and raising money for the Maloga Mission cause.<ref name="Pathfinders"/> He also lived on the Warangesda Mission in the early 1890s.<ref name="Pathfinders"/>
In February 1897 Whyman became a tracker for the New South Wales police, based at [[Tumbarumba]].<ref name="Pathfinders"/><ref>{{Citation | author1=Frew, Ron | author2=Patten, John, (contributing author.) | author3=Murray Local Land Service (sponsoring body) | title=Police trackers Tumbarumba : 1864-1927 : an initial survey | publication-date=2016 | publisher=Tumbarumba, [New South Wales] Ron Frew | url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/work/206490020 | accessdate=24 January 2018 }}</ref> After five years he transferred to [[Wagga Wagga]].<ref name="Pathfinders"/> He served 28 years at the police station in Wagga and worked on cases as far afield as Gundagai.<ref name="NW Champion">{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article181565591 |title=News in Brief |newspaper=[[North West Champion]] |volume=13, |issue=11 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=12 February 1925 |accessdate=24 January 2018 |page=3 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article121746853 |title=ALL ABOUT PEOPLE. |newspaper=[[The Gundagai Independent And Pastoral, Agricultural And Mining Advocate]] |issue=2646 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=5 February 1925 |accessdate=24 January 2018 |page=2 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> During his time on the police force he was responsible for the recovery of 34 bodies of people who had drowned in the [[Murrumbidgee River]].<ref name="NW Champion"/> He was also instrumental in tracking and capturing up to 120 fugitives who were brought before the courts.<ref name="NW Champion"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article7287157 |title=HAYSTACKS BURNT. |newspaper=[[The Argus (Melbourne)]] |issue=21,068 |location=Victoria, Australia |date=2 February 1914 |accessdate=24 January 2018 |page=6 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article121769851 |title=ELECTRICITY. |newspaper=[[The Gundagai Times And Tumut, Adelong And Murrumbidgee District Advertiser]] |issue=7390 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=6 February 1925 |accessdate=24 January 2018 |page=2 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article145394161 |title=SMART CAPTURE |newspaper=[[Wagga Wagga Express]] |volume=53, |issue=9309 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=11 January 1913 |accessdate=24 January 2018 |page=2 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
Whyman McLean fell ill in December 1926 and was taken to [[Callan Park Hospital for the Insane|Callan Park Hospital]] in Sydney where he died on 23 December 1926.<ref name="Pathfinders"/>
